tourName: Best of New Zealand private holiday
generalInfo: See the best of New Zealand in three weeks taking in the thermal splendours of Rotorua on North Island and the majestic alpine scenery of Fiordland in the south, with some unforgettable experiences en route.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Auckland We greet you on arrival at the airport and take you to your hotel where you can relax before getting to know the ‘City of Sails’.

Day 2 Auckland A great start to city sightseeing is to ascend the Sky Tower: a SkyWalk is optional! Nearby Queen Street is the main strip and you could end your day with a waterfront dinner in the new Wynyard Quarter.
Auckland – Waitomo – Rotorua Collect a rental vehicle and head south to Waitomo Glow Worm caves before being continuing to Rotorua.

Rotorua From the Buried Village to Whakarewarewa, Te Puia ( The Maori Arts and Crafts Institute) and Waimangu: all fascinating attractions that blend the two aspects that make Rotorua a must: Maori culture and geothermal activity. We can also recommend an authentic Maori hangi for dinner!

Rotorua – Tongariro National Park/ Napier On the road south, make time to see the Lady Knox Geyser at Wai O Tapu Geothermal Park. Stop in Taupo for lunch before entering Tongariro National Park, a starkly beautiful volcanic landscape. (Alternatively head east to the Art Deco town of Napier.)

Tongariro National Park (or Napier) Often described as the finest one day walk in NZ, the Tongariro Crossing is a full day traverse of the ‘saddle’ between Mts Tongariro and Ngauruhoe. Shorter walks are also possible. A round of golf on an all-weather course, or a soak in a natural hot pool are other options

Tongariro (or Napier) – Wellington Travel through country towns to Wellington, still the ‘coolest little capital in the world’ thanks to its combination of location, architecture, café culture and laid-back lifestyle. Stroll through Civic Square to a Queens Wharf restaurant.
Wellington – Picton – Nelson Board the Interislander ferry to cruise to South Island, and drive to Nelson, the sunniest town in New Zealand.

Abel Tasman National Park It is easy to gush about the beauty of Abel Tasman National Park! Golden beaches, turquoise water and pristine native bush combine to create a natural paradise you can explore by boat, kayak or on foot. We have plenty of tips for you.
Nelson- Christchurch Depart Nelson by scheduled coach service travelling to Blenheim to join the Coastal Pacific train for a delightful journey down the East Coast via Kaikoura to Christchurch

Christchurch- Hokitika Depart Christchurch on the Tranz Alpine Train for a scenic rail journey through the splendour of the Southern Alps to the West Coast. Pick up your rental car in Greymouth and travel south down the western coastline with the Southern Alps to the east and the Tasman Sea to the west to the town of Hokitika.

Hokitika – Fox Glacier Hokitika, once a gold rush town, is now a haven for craftspeople and a good place to buy pounamu (greenstone) carvings. Arrive in Fox in time to see the glacier on a guided hike or helicopter trip: landing on the Tasman Glacier is an unforgettable experience!
Fox - Wanaka Travel south through native rainforest, over mountain streams into the rugged beauty of the Haast Pass. Continue round the shores of glacial Hawea and Wanaka lakes to Wanaka township

Wanaka One of our favourite destinations, the snow-capped peaks, long river valleys and lush native forest are centred around the beautiful lake. There are ‘tramping’ opportunities for every experience level and the opportunity to enjoy an eco adventure on Mou Waho Island where a local guide will take you to on a short walk with the possibility to view rare weka birds and to help with the re-afforestation of native trees on the island
Wanaka A jet boat trip or a waterfall climb are both guaranteed to set the pulses racing. In the evening, take a seat at Cinema Paradiso: they range from slouchy sofas to a modified Morris Minor!
Wanaka- Te Anau Travel through Central Otago, around the shores of Lake Wakatipu to Te Anau, one of Fiordland’s most beautiful lakes. Round off the day with a lakeside stroll.

Te Anau – Milford Sound – Te Anau An early start for one of the world’s most scenic coach trips! Travelling through the National Park is integral to the Milford Sound experience. On arrival, a cruise on the Sound reveals vertiginous cliffs, cascading waterfalls and awesome Mitre Peak.
Te Anau – Queenstown Drive to Queenstown, sometimes called the ‘Switzerland of the Southern Hemisphere’ and superbly set on Lake Wakatipu.
Queenstown So much to do, so little time! Stroll in well-kept gardens, cruise Lake Wakatipu or try an adrenalin activity like bungy jumping or an off-road 4X4 tour.
Queenstown – Mt Cook Drive through Mackenzie Country to Lake Pukaki and up to Mt Cook Village.
Day at leisure for your choice of activities Short walks to Kea Point or into the Hooker Valley offer wonderful mountain views. .

Mt Cook – Christchurch Make an early stop at the Church of the Good Shepherd, whose altar window frames Lake Tekapo. Cross the tussock plains, so evocative of sheep country, through Fairlie and Geraldine to arrive in Christchurch.

Christchurch Following 2011’s earthquake, this Garden City is rebuilding, blending old (Botanic Gardens, River Avon and the Tram) with new (the Cardboard Cathedral, Container Mall and countless pop-up bars) to reclaim its place as the premier city of South Island.
Depart Christchurch Transfer to Christchurch Airport for your flight home, or ask us about dovetailing this itinerary with one of our Small Group Journeys to extend your time in New Zealand.

tourName: Boutique self drive tour of New Zealand
generalInfo: This comprehensive 27-day itinerary explores the North and South Island’s iconic destinations with plenty of two-night stays to ensure you really experience New Zealand. From the vibrant city of Auckland to the tropical Bay of Islands, you’ll also visit the cultural mecca of Rotorua and Wellington City before crossing the Cook Strait to Marlborough at the top of the South Island. Kaikoura and its famous wildlife can be explored before continuing south towards the Southern Alps and Mt Cook National Park. Stay in the adventure capital Queenstown and see the West Coast Glaciers before returning to Christchurch via the world famous TranzAlpine train. You’ll also spend time in more out of the way locations such as Hawke's Bay and Abel Tasman National Park. Experience the diverse geography between the north and south, spectacular landscapes and the rich wildlife that inhabits our land and seas. This tour has something for everyone.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Auckland! You will be met on arrival and taken to your city hotel.
A full day free to explore Auckland City, head up the Sky Tower with the best views over the city, or climb to the top of Mt Eden volcano. End your day with a Harbour Dinner Cruise.
Explore Waiheke Island at your leisure today with a Hop On Hop Off Bus Tour. The buses stop at some of the island's iconic spots including Oneroa Village, Onetangi Beach, and several vineyards.
Collect your rental car, then drive north to the tropical Bay of Islands.
Embark on a Hole in the Rock Cruise along the Rakaumangamanga Peninsula to Cape Brett, where a historic lighthouse keeps watch over and Piercy Island.
Free day to explore and drive round the Bay of Islands, made up of over 140 subtropical atolls.
Drive from Paihia to Waitakere Estate via Waipoua Forest today.
Time to head south today to Rotorua. Along the way stop at the town of Matamata made famous in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and enjoy a tour of the set.

Explore Rotorua today, with natural hot springs, boiling mud pools and steaming geysers. Visit Te Puia for a living Maori cultural experience, followed by Te Pa Tu evening cultural experience at Tamaki Maori Village.
Dive to Lake Taupo and enjoy a thrilling Jet Boat Ride up to the base of the foaming Huka Falls.
Drive to Napier today, the beachside city with a seaport on the eastern coast and the seat of the Hawke's Bay region.
Explore Napier and the Hawke's Bay, we recommend going on a wine tour of this famous region of vineyards.
Time to drive to the very south of the North Island to the vibrant capital city of Wellington.
Free day in Wellington, often referred to as ‘mini-Melbourne’, the city has a cosmopolitan feel and melting pot of art, culture, food and fashion.

Depart the North Island today on the Interislander Ferry from Wellington via the stunning landscape of the Cook Strait, described as 'one of the most beautiful ferry rides in the world'. Drive to Nelson to overnight.
Free day in Nelson and time to explore close by Abel Tasman National Park, with white sandy beaches and crystal clear waters. Popular for kayaking and various watersports.
Drive to Blenheim, the town at the heart of the New Zealand's largest wine producing region, Marlborough.
Free day to enjoy sampling the local produce on many of the vineyard tours available.
Drive an hour south to Kaikoura on the east coast today, the best place for whale watching. With the rest of the day free.
Morning free morning, we recommend a whale or dolphin watching tour before heading to Christchurch to overnight.
Drive to the stunning Aoraki Mount Cook National Park today and spend the afternoon exploring one of the many walking tracks.
Experience an unforgettable glacier tour today. Experience 500-year-old icebergs up-close on the Mt Cook terminal lake from the safety of a specially designed boat.
Head to the adventure capital of New Zealand, Queenstown today.
Free day in Queenstown to explore and enjoy activities.
Drive to Franz Josef Glacier stop en route at the beautiful Lake Wanaka with its azure blue water.
Drop your rental car at the Greymouth Train Station and take the TranzAlpine Scenic Train Greymouth to Christchurch.
Say farewell from New Zealand. Have a private transfer accommodation to Christchurch Airport.

tourName: Complete tour of New Zealand
generalInfo:
The Complete New Zealand 32 day Tailor-Made itinerary that combines unforgettable scenic highlights and experiences with outstanding hotel and bed & breakfast accommodation.

Take a guided wine tour in Hawkes Bay, electro bike along the traffic free cycle path out of Queenstown to Jack's Point and try your hand at panning for gold in Arrowtown.

This self drive holiday allows you to see the length and breadth of the country at your own pace. Travel up to the Bay of Islands at the top of North Island for the opportunity to swim with dolphins and cruise to the 'hole on the rock', and down to Milford Sound at the bottom of South Island, to experience a nature cruise through to the Tasman sea.

dayInfo.description: Haere mai – welcome! We greet your flight and take you straight to your accommodation for the next two nights. The rest of your day is at leisure. Head up the Sky Tower for great views across the city, or explore the vibrant downtown waterfront.

A day to explore the islands of the Hauraki Maritime Gulf, take the ferry to Rangitoto Island and walk up to the summit for 360° views or head to the conservation island of Tiritiri Matangi to see rare native birds such as the Takahe and the Kokako.

Collect your rental vehicle and drive north along the Hibiscus Coast Highway to the Waipoua Forest to learn about the ancient Kauri trees, including ‘the lord of the forest’ Tane Mahuta. Follow the path of the Ngapuhi Iwi warriors to the Flagstaff battlegrounds and on to the pretty seaside town of Paihia.
Cruise to Cape Brett and the ‘hole in the rock’, head out into the bay with a chance to swim with dolphins, and learn a little more of local village Russell’s rip-roaring past on a guided tour.

Begin your day at the Waitangi Treaty Grounds, where ‘modern’ New Zealand was in essence founded on the signing of the 1840 treaty between Maori tribes and British settlers. Enter the magnificent meeting house, be awestruck at the size of the war canoe and stroll across the lawns for views over the sea.

Head south, through the Waikato to the Miranda Shorebird Centre to learn about some of New Zealand’s most fascinating birdlife and onto the beautiful Coromandel Peninsula. Stroll the beautiful beaches of the Coromandel.
Dig your own spa pool at Hot Water Beach, or wander along the beach to Cathedral Cove to view the naturally formed archway on the beach, one of the most photographed sites in the country.

On to the thermal wonderland of Rotorua. Visit Te Puia with its geothermal valley and Maori Arts and Crafts Institute. In the evening enjoy a cultural experience that culminates with a traditional Maori Hangi for your evening meal.

Stroll the Government Gardens and visit the Victorian Bathouse . Head out to Waimangu Valley for a leisurely walk through the valley of steaming geysers , mud pools and lakes . In the evening enjoy a cultural experience that culminates with a traditional Maori Hangi for your evening meal.

Travel south to Taupo, nestled on the shores of New Zealand’s largest lake, stopping at Huka Falls before continuing through to the township. From here drive to Napier, a wonderful Art Deco town with a fascinating history and wonderful architecture. The town is also the gateway to the Hawkes Bay wine country.

We recommend leaving the car at home today, and hiring bikes to make the most of the winery tours and tastings that are a must in the area. Head out to Te Mata Peak to enjoy the beautiful panoramic views out across the mountain ranges
Drive through the Wairarapa and over the winding Rimutaka Hill to arrive into Wellington, the Capital City and ‘The Coolest Little Capital in the World’ according to The Lonely Planet Guides.

Spend the day exploring New Zealand’s compact capital city. Take the Cable Car up to the Kelburn lookout and wander back down through the Botanic Gardens, stopping off for tea in the Lady Rosewood Garden. Alternatively immerse yourself in history and culture at Te Papa, New Zealand’s National Museum.

Board the Interislander Ferry for the cruise across the Cook Strait and through the scenic Queen Charlotte Sound to the South Island. Arrive into Picton and drive across the top of the South Island to Nelson, your base for the next two nights.

Transfer by coach from Nelson to Kaiteriteri for a cruise into the heart of Abel Tasman National Park. Walk the most varied section of the Abel Tasman Coastal Track, along a path that weaves through Manuka groves to the long golden sands of Anchorage beach. Return to Kaiteriteri by boat then on to Nelson by coach.
Depart Nelson by coach or car and travel via the Lewis Pass or Blenheim to the city of Christchurch, passing through Kaikoura en route. (Return your car in Christchurch.)

Board the Tranzalpine train for one of the world’s greatest rail journeys through the splendour of the Southern Alps to the West Coast. Travel alongside the ice-fed Waimakariri River to Arthur’s Pass before continuing on to Greymouth. Collect your rental car and drive down the West Coast to Hokitika, famed for its gold mining heritage.

Travel to the Fox and Franz Josef glaciers and take a walk to the terminal face. Enjoy a guided heli-hike or sightseeing flight to experience the glacier close up. Drive to Lake Matheson for superb reflections of Mount Cook and the Tasman glacier. Remember to bring your camera!
Drive through the stunning Haast Pass and into Mount Aspiring National Park. Arrive into Wanaka, and enjoy views of the lake that reflect the mountain peaks that in winter offer superb skiing.

Enjoy lakeside walks, or an exhilarating jet boat trip on the Matukituki River, guaranteed to set the pulse racing! Relax in the evening at Cinema Paradiso, with its comfy sofas and even a classic Morris Minor to sit in to view the latest releases.
A day at leisure or for more activities , perhaps a trip into the high mountains for amazing views of the Park or an eco adventure to Mou Waho Island where you can plant a native tree
Today it’s an easy drive over the Crown Range to Queenstown, New Zealand’s adventure playground and South Island’s busiest resort. Spend the afternoon exploring this action packed little town.

Take a short drive out to Arrowtown, or ride up the Skyline Gondola for panoramic views of the area. Local wineries welcome visitors for tastings and tours and the classic steamship TSS Earnslaw is an unforgettable way to discover Lake Wakatipu.

Journey by coach through the stunning valleys and past the ‘mirror’ lakes to reach Milford Sound. Board the Milford Mariner to cruise the Sound, learning about its geology, flora and fauna from the on-board expert, before anchoring in a sheltered cove. Absorb the beauty from a seat on deck, or kayak closer to Milford’s mystery.

Return from Milford by coach to the township of Te Anau , located on the shores of Lake Te Anau . Enjoy some downtime after your overnight trip and relax in your beautiful surroundings .Walks along the shoreline or part of the Kepler track or boat trips are other possibilities.
Drive along the shores of Lake Te Anau and through the sheep farming heartland of South Island and on to the city of Dunedin.

Take a trip out to the Otago Peninsula to see the Royal Albatross at Taiaroa heads, and the Little Blue Penguins that nestle in sandy burrows on the beaches. In the city itself, the Railway Station is a stunning example of the city’s fabulous architecture.

Head north along the coast, stopping to view the extraordinary Moeraki Boulders, before heading inland to Mount Cook National Park. Drive along the western shore of Lake Pukaki with its intensely blue glacier-fed waters.

A day amongst an amazing mountain panorama . Named Aoraki ,’ the cloud piercer’ by the Maoris, Mount Cook is the highest mountain in the Southern Hemisphere. This is an International Dark Sky Reserve and at the Mount John Observatory you can see galaxies ‘far far away’.

Head down the Tasman Valley from Mount Cook and on to Lake Tekapo and the Church of the Good Shepherd, where the window behind the altar frames an astonishing view of the lake. Then across the high country’s tussock plains, through Fairlie and Geraldine to the ‘Garden City’ of Christchurch.

Today explore Christchurch. Enjoy a guided walking tour and learn how the city is reclaiming its place as the premier city on South Island after the devastating earthquakes of 2011. Take a short drive out to the Port Hills for excellent walks, or to the French settlement and harbour town of Akaroa.
After breakfast return your rental vehicle to Christchurch International airport to board your homebound flight via Auckland.

tourName: Honeymoon in New Zealand
generalInfo:
This epic self-drive New Zealand honeymoon combines romance, luxury and adventure to create an itinerary of unforgettable experiences, which you and your partner can look back on fondly in the years to come.

You’ll start with a luxury glamping experience on the banks of the Takou River, complete with floating rose petals in your outdoor bath; a secluded escape designed just for two. Sail through the magical Bay of Island on your own private chartered catamaran, then climb the Southern Alps via a scenic ride on the TranzAlpine Express.

Indulge in another luxury glamping experience on the edge of the Kaniere River, shaded by ancient forest. Then, enjoy a unique private tour of the remote Hokitika area with a ride along the sacred Arahura River to find greenstone, guided by the son of a paramount Maori chief.

Next, it’s three days in Queenstown, where you'll take a helicopter tour of Fiordland National Park, cruise through the Milford Sound, choose from a range of adrenaline-pumping outdoor activities, then unwind in natural hot spring pools, followed by a gourmet feast of culinary options, from traditional Kiwi cuisine to local boutique wines.

This romantic New Zealand honeymoon is perfect for the adventurous couple ready to take on the world together.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Auckland & Transfer to Takou River – Flying into Auckland, you’ll take a 30-minute internal flight to Kerikeri, where you will pick up your hire car and your dream New Zealand honeymoon truly begins. You’ll drive to Magic Cottages, known as one of the best luxury lodges in the country, located on the shores of Takou River. Your luxury glamping site is hidden in a secluded corner of the 150-acre organic farm, offering privacy and intimate moments with your loved one. Spend the evening stargazing from your private deck, relax in the outdoor bath overlooking the water, then drift off to sleep listening to the relaxing sounds of the trickling river.

Sailing the Bay of Islands – Drive to Paihai for an exclusive boat charter around the Bay of Islands. Your 54-foot sailing catamaran includes private cabins, an outdoor dining area, a spacious lounge and even trampolines in the bows, perfect for dolphin watching. You’ll sail through the subtropical archipelago, with stop-offs on remote beaches and ancient Maori sites, as well as opportunities for water sports such as swimming, snorkelling, paddle-boarding and kayaking through glittering azure waters.

Exploring Takou River – Today, you are free to explore your surroundings at your leisure. We recommend a drive to the arching cascades of Haruru Falls, shaped like a horseshoe. Start the walking trail that begins at the waterfall for a boardwalk trek through the mangroves to Waitangi, an historic Maori cultural site. Continuing to Henderson Bay, try quad biking across the sands of Great Exhibition Bay. Then, head up to Cape Reinga, where the Tasman Sea meets the Pacific Ocean in a churn of currents, and take note of the ancient and sacred pohutukawa tree. According to Maori legend, those who pass away leap from the tree into the ocean, leaving this world and starting their journey to the ancestral homeland.

Transfer to Christchurch – Leave your luxury campsite behind and return to Kerikeri airport, where you’ll drop off your hire car and take a flight down to South Island’s Christchurch, via Auckland. You’ll be staying at Hotel 115, a locally-owned boutique hotel located in the city centre and only a stone’s throw from Cathedral Square. Explore the Christchurch Botanic Gardens, meander along the Avon River, visit Ferrymead Heritage Park, or simply recline on Summer Beach.

TranzAlpine Train Journey & Transfer to Hokitika – Take a scenic train journey across the Canterbury Plains and ascend the Southern Alps, via the TranzAlpine Express. Stretching from the east coast to the west, the trip offers endless views of river valleys, mountains and farmlands, ending in Greymouth. From here, you’ll pick up your next rental car and head to Hurunui Jacks in Hokitika for your next luxury glamping experience, complete with riverside seclusion, ancient forest surroundings and opulent outdoor bathing.

Exploring the Hokitika Area – Today, you’ll meet Bevan Climo, the son of a paramount chief of the Hokitika region and an expert guide on the area. He’ll take you on a private and exclusive tour along the Arahua, a sacred river over accessible by Maori, where you'll learn how to find and carve pounamu (greenstone).

Exploring the Hokitika Area – Explore the Hokitika region at your leisure today. We recommend a visit to Hokitika Gorge, where you can walk along a swing bridge and look down at the brilliant blue waters and lush green forest below. Then, explore the upper branches of the region’s ancient forests via the West Coast Treetop Walk. There’s also the option to visit nearby Punakaiki, known for the Pancake Rocks and vertical blowholes at high tide.

Transfer to Queenstown – Head to the airport and drop off your rental car before taking a flight down to Queenstown, via Christchurch. From here, you’ll pick up your next hire car and head to the five-star Queenstown Park Boutique Hotel, located within gorgeous parklands, walking distance from the city centre and Lake Wakatipu. Settle in with pre-dinner drinks and canapes at the hotel, which are made using locally-sourced ingredients, then wander into the city to try out some of the many wining and dining options available.

Helicopter Tour & Milford Sound Cruise – Today, you’ll embark on a helicopter adventure over Fiordland National Park, where you’ll be treated to bird’s eye views of dense forests, rolling farmlands and stunning alpine scenery of lakes, waterfalls and valleys. You’ll land at Milford Sound for a cruise around the remote valley, renowned for it’s tranquil atmosphere and spectacular mountain scenery. On your return helicopter flight, you’ll be able to see ice shelves and can even stop off on a glacier to take in your surrounding and take some photos too.

Exploring Queenstown – Head up the Queenstown Hill Time Walk for 360-degree views, take a trip to charming Glenorchy for a hike around Lake Sylvan, or sample the region’s famous vinos and vintages on a winery tour . If you’re looking for a surge of adrenaline, Queenstown is known for being a thrill-seeking paradise, with activities including bungy jumping, zip-lining, skydiving, canyoning, paragliding and rafting on offer. Stop for lunch at Amisfield Winery for vineyard and mountain vistas, as well as world-class cuisine by Michelin-star chef, Vaughan Mabee. Then, round off your New Zealand honeymoon with a romantic dip at the Onsen Hot Pools, where you can sip on champagne, looking out to the Shotover River Canyons.

Departure from Queenstown – Sadly, your New Zealand adventure honeymoon comes to an end, but you’ll leave with plenty of entertaining stories and unforgettable experiences from your first trip together as a married couple.

tourName: Luxury self drive holiday in New Zealand
generalInfo:
Discover the very best of New Zealand, from breathtaking natural scenery to world-class hotels and lodges; from steaming geysers to frozen waterfalls, and from vibrant cities to rugged mountain outcrops. This self-drive adventure holiday is ideal for those keen to explore New Zealand’s rich culture and awe-inspiring landscapes, with an added treat of Kiwi cuisine and boutique wines.

You’ll begin in Auckland, making a trip over to Waiheke Island for a gourmet food and wine tour, before driving down to the enchanting glowworm caves of Waitomo. Next, you’ll venture into the Kaimanawa Ranges with a Maori guide, marvel at the jewel tones of Wai-O-Tapu’s geothermal pools, and tour renowned wineries in Hawke’s Bay.

Flying down to the South Island, you’ll explore Christchurch, then climb the Southern Alps aboard the scenic TranzAlpine express train. A helicopter ride over the awe-inspiring landscapes of Aoraki Mount Cook National Park and the Tasman Glacier will leave you speechless, while a jetboat ride through the Shotover River Canyons will get the adrenaline flowing!

You’ll stay in luxury accommodations, ranging from opulent boutique hotels adorned with modern art to peaceful lakeside retreats—perfect for unwinding after a day of adventure.

This luxury tour is custom-designed to meet your every need, creating an itinerary that will make you fall in love with New Zealand.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Auckland – You’ll be met at Auckland Airport by a private chauffeur, who will transfer your accommodation, in Auckland's city centre. Have a drink at the historic House bar, grab dinner in the glass-roofed atrium of DeBrett’s kitchen, or try local craft beers and boutique wines at the retro-chic Cornerbar.

Wine & Gourmet Food Tour of Waiheke Island – Board your ferry and enjoy the scenic 40-minute cruise to Waiheke Island. This stunning island just off the Auckland coast boasts 92 square kilometres of beautiful beaches, vineyards, olive groves, native bush and laid back seaside villages. Some sailings will include a brief stop in Devonport on the way to Waiheke Island. After all this sampling, enjoy a two-course lunch at one of the island’s best restaurants.

Glowworm Grottos of Waitomo – Pick up your rental car to start your self-drive tour of New Zealand’s legendary countryside. You will pass the small town of Pokeno and then you will come alongside New Zealand's longest river - the Waikato River. Keep an eye out for Mount Pirongia as you head further South - an extinct volcano and Waikato's highest peak. Waitomo, located in the heart of North Island, where you can explore natural wonders such as limestone caves, underground pools and glowworm grottos. Then, you’ll drive on to your next accommodation and unwind with pre-dinner drinks and canapes, plus a chance to chat with your local hosts and fellow guests.

Learning About Maori Culture – Meet your private guide, you will be taken to the New Zealand Maori Arts and Crafts Institute and taken on a VIP experience through geothermal valley and arts schools and walk through the geothermal valley. Learn more about the carving and weaving schools while your host gives you in-depth insight in to how the inner workings of the facility and its importance to the Maori culture. Meet your private chef who has prepared an amazing, geothermally cooked, Maori inspired feast for your enjoyment. Paired with local wines and beers, sit, eat and devour the delicious food prepped freshly for you while listening to one of the local artists sing Maori songs. Enjoy leisurely sightseeing around the Rotorua area. You have the option to walk trails such as Tikitapu, the Redwoods, Okere Falls and more.

Wai-O-Tapu Thermal Wonderland – Today, you’ll enjoy a private guided tour of the ancient geothermal site of Wai-O-Tapu, featuring vivid green pools formed by the region’s volcanic activity. Sculptured out of volcanic activity and thousands of years in the making, Wai-O-Tapu is considered to be New Zealand’s most colourful and diverse geothermal sightseeing attraction. Marvel at erupting geysers, bubbling mud pools and natural hot springs.

Transfer to Napier – Today, depart leave Taupo and head over to the east coast to the Art Deco Capital of the World, Napier. Drive through the beautiful scenery on the way to Napier from Taupo with rugged hills, beautiful valleys, gentle plains and huge vistas. Descend into the fertile Hawke's Bay Province and make your way into the city of Napier.

Exclusive Tour of Hawke's Bay – Today, you will explore the Hawke’s Bay region and take in the expansive views Take in the natural beauty and local produce, including lunch at one of the area’s top wineries. Take in gorgeous views at Cape Kidnappers and Te Mata Peak, then wander the streets of Napier, admiring the Art-Deco architecture (Napier has the highest concentration of Art Deco buildings in the world). Here you will stay at The Manse.

Transfer to Christchurch – Drop off your rental car at Napier Airport and take a flight down to South Island’s Christchurch, via Wellington. From here, you’ll be met by a private chauffeur and transferred to your accommodation and enjoy exploring this wonderful city.

Arthur's Pass National Park – Take a scenic train ride on the TranzAlpine, across the Canterbury Plains and up the Southern Alps, to arrive at Arthur’s Pass National Park. You’ll take a private guided tour of the park, customised to your preferences and the weather. We recommend the hike up to Waimakariri River Valley, with a picnic stop along the trail. After a wonderful day exploring you will head back to Christchurch for the night.

Aoraki Mount Cook National Park & the Tasman Glacier – Collect your next rental car and drive to Aoraki Mount Cook National Park. Depart Christchurch and travel across the Canterbury Plains through fields and farms. The longest bridge in New Zealand takes you across the Rakaia River, a typical New Zealand ‘braided river’ where numerous channels of water flow across a wide gravel bed. Shortly after crossing the Rangitata River, turn inland to Geraldine - the gateway to the lakes in the central Mackenzie Basin. This is the perfect place to stop for a coffee. Travel onwards through Lake Tekapo, where the picturesque Church of the Good Shepherd perches on the lakeside. Continue through a landscape of scrub and tussock to Lake Pukaki and drive up the western shore, following the Tasman River to Mt Cook village.

Transfer to Queenstown – This morning you will head out With your professional mountain guide, you will fly high onto the white ice of New Zealand’s longest glacier – the mighty Tasman. Check in at Mt Cook Airport for a safety briefing and equipment check before embarking on a thrilling helicopter flight into the mountains. You will land at 1,200 metres above sea level and spend up to two hours on a guided interpretative ice trek. The helicopter will return you to Mt Cook Airport, flying close by the massive 1,000 metre high (3,200 feet) Hochstetter Icefall below Aoraki Mount Cook to finish this amazing adventure. Next, you’ll drive further south to Queenstown and to your chosen accommodation.

Queenstown, Ben Lomond High Country Sheep Station – Enjoy a half-day farm expedition with a trip to Ben Lomond High Country Sheep Station. Soak up the region’s history and take in 360-degree alpine views, as you learn about New Zealand’s agriculture. You’ll stop in at historic Seffers Town, which was once a gold rush tent village in the mid-1800’s. Here your guide will explain the fascinating history of the area whilst you enjoy a gourmet picnic lunch. You will be able to enter the very hut that Barry Crump, a famous New Zealand author and man of the land lived and wrote. Following lunch you’ll be guided back out and then transferred back to your accommodation.

Jetboat Ride on the Shotover River – Have a relaxing morning exploring the lakeside surroundings of Rosewood Matakauri, navigating quirky Queenstown and taking a ride on the city’s Skyline Gondola. After lunch, board your jet boat at Shotover Beach on the banks of the Shotover River, known as the world's richest gold bearing river, the Shotover's rugged canyons have been carved over thousands of years by billions of tonnes of glacial water sluicing from the heart of the Southern Alps.

Departure from New Zealand – Your two-week luxury New Zealand adventure comes to an end, but you'll be flying out of Queenstown Airport with a heart full of happy memories, a camera packed with amazing photos and many stories to tell loved ones back home.

tourName: Malborough Sounds small ship cruise in New Zealand
generalInfo:
Discover the tranquil waterways, wildlife and rich history of New Zealand’s Marlborough Sounds on an unforgettable 7-day Kiwi adventure exploring Queen Charlotte and Pelorus Sounds, French Pass and d’Urville Island.

Famed for the breath-taking beauty of their winding cobalt waterways, iconic landscapes, lush native forests, wildlife and remote coastlines these regions are also rich in early New Zealand history and the location of some of the country’s most important conservation efforts.

Formed by a system of submerged valleys carved out following the last ice age around 10,000 years ago, the scenic playground of Marlborough Sounds encompasses some 1,500-kilometres of forested coastline, sheltered inlets and bays awaiting exploration, many only accessible by sea. The union of three main bodies of water – Queen Charlotte, Kenepuru and Pelorus Sounds – Marlborough Sounds has more than 50 Department of Conservation managed reserves and several predator free wildlife sanctuaries.

Just 500 treacherous metres from the mainland, d’Urville Island was named after French admiral Jules Sebastian Cesar Dumont d’Urville and his ill fated passage of the infamous French Pass in January 1827.

After several near misses while seeking passage inside the island, he came close to losing his ship Astrolabe after hitting the reef. Now a possum, rat and weasel-free conservation reserve, d’Urville Island is one of the last strongholds of the critically endangered Long-tailed Bat and provides a respite for the world’s rarest shag – the King Shag – and several other species of rare birds and geckos.

A voyage of adventure and discovery awaits in the Marlborough Sounds.

dayInfo.description: Blenheim Make your way to the designated meeting point in Blenheim for your transfer to our ship in Picton (times and meeting point will be confirmed with your voyage documents). The captain and expedition team will be waiting to welcome you aboard Heritage Explorer and show you to your cabin. You will have the opportunity to familiarise yourself on board then join fellow travellers and your expedition team as we set sail along Queen Charlotte Sound this afternoon. ***Note: Some voyages will operate the itinerary in reverse.***

Queen Charlotte Sound First sighted in 1642 by Abel Janszoon Tasman while seeking shelter for his ships Heemskerck and Zeehaen from a storm near d’Urville Island, it was Captain James Cook who would first set foot here aboard the Endeavour during his five visits to Ship Cove, his New Zealand base between 1770 and 1777, in what he would call Queen Charlotte Sound. We spend two full days exploring the waterways and islands of scenic Queen Charlotte Sound with opportunities to head ashore and walk a section of the Queen Charlotte Walkway as well as search for birdlife on the predator-free islands. A visit to Tory Channel brings the whaling history of the Perano Whalers to life. We also plan to visit Ship Cove and learn of its history, exploring the region and visiting Captain Cook’s memorial inaugurated in 1913. Another conservation success story, Blumine Island has seen the translocation of several rare bird species including the once widespread Orange-fronted Parakeet, now New Zealand’s rarest parakeet, which were translocated to the island between 2011 and 2012. Also thriving on the island are South Island Saddleback, brought back from the brink of extinction last century from just 36 birds rescued in 1964, descendants of these birds were translocated to Blumine Island in 2009.

d’Urville island Today we sail through the iconic French Pass and the wake of French Explorer Dumont d’Urville and then explore the island named in his honour. The outermost island in the Marlborough Sounds, d’Urville Island features imposing sea cliffs along its west coast, a high mountainous backbone and the fastest moving tidal flows in New Zealand between the French Pass tempered by some of the country’s finest peninsula scenery. Dolphins and New Zealand Fur Seals are frequently seen in the waters surrounding the island and it was here that Pelorus Jack, the endearing Risso’s Dolphin who famously stole the nation’s heart, guided ships across the dangerous waters of Cook Strait between 1888 and 1912.

Pelorus Sound The largest in the Marlborough Sounds, Pelorus Sound’s main channel winds some picturesque 55-kilometres south between steep verdant hills from Cook Strait to Havelock. Boasting 380-kilometres of shoreline, the endless bays and sheltered coves of Pelorus Sound are perfect for exploration. Venturing into Pelorus Sound we head to Ngawhakawhiti Bay where nature surrounds us and it’s possible to get a glimpse of what the sounds would have been like before the native forest was cleared. The more active are able to enjoy the walking part of the Nydia Track before we explore Nydia Bay. Tonight we will enjoy a farewell dinner and celebrate our adventure.

Blenheim We arrive into the inner reaches of Pelorous Sound this morning. After a final breakfast and farewells, a Zodiac tender takes you ashore at Havelock where a transfer to a central Blenheim drop off point or the airport waits. In case of unexpected delays we ask you not to book any onward travel from Blenheim until after midday today. During our voyage, circumstances may make it necessary or desirable to deviate from the proposed itinerary. This can include poor weather and opportunities for making unplanned excursions. Your Expedition Leader will keep you fully informed.

tourName: Nature tour in New Zealand
placesVisited: Bay of Islands, Tiritiri Matangi Island Reserve, 'Kiwi Dundee' on the Coromandel Peninsula, Maori culture in Rotorua, Wellington, Karori Wildlife Sanctuary, Kaikoura, Antarctic Centre in Christchurch, Southern Alps, Penguins on the Otago Peninsula, Stewart Island, Ruggedy Range Wilderness Experience, Milford Sound, Lord of the Rings landscapes around Queenstown
generalInfo:
New Zealand is blessed with an abundance of birdlife and a pristine natural environment and this itinerary includes some of the best natural wonders that New Zealand has to offer. You will journey through the heart of New Zealand visiting areas that showcase the diversity of the natural environment and its inhabitants.

This itinerary includes a visit to the island reserve of Tiritiri Matangi, renowned for its abundance of native birdlife, and two nights on Stewart Island, 85% of which is a national park and one of the places where you are likely to see the rare Kiwi. You will get the opportunity to take a boat out in to the waters around Kaikoura on the lookout for sperm whales and dolphins and spend some time on the Otago peninsula, best known for its protected colonies of royal albatross and the rare yellow-eyed penguin.

You will also get the chance to spend some time in the company of some of New Zealand's most knowledgable and enthusiastic nature guides like Kiwi Dundee on the Coromandel Peninsula. You will learn more about how the environment and culture go hand in hand in this country through visiting Te Puia Maori cultural experience in Rotorua.

Throughout your journey you will experience fantastic scenery, much of which is preserved in New Zealand's 14 National Parks, with everything from gorgeous beaches and untouched native forest to spectacular geothermal activity and dramatic mountain peaks.

Best time to go: In order to include all the activities and excursions outlined in this itinerary, it would be advisable to avoid the winter months, namely June, July and August. The ideal time to visit New Zealand in terms of the weather is from late spring and through the summer, any time from November until the end of April, with February being the busiest month for international tourists.

dayInfo.description: Arrive in the Bay of Islands. Pick up an economy car from the airport and make you way to your accommodation. Stay at the beautiful Arcadia Lodge, a small locally owner B&B that used recycled Kauri Tree wood to refurbish the property.
Join a half day sailing boat trip to try to spot dolphins and marine life in bay.
Today drive south just shy of Auckland, where you will spend the next two nights.
Take the ferry to Tiritiri Matangi, an Island reserve, and be guided through the bush whilst looking for an array of native birds.
Drive to the Coromandel Peninsula, via Miranda and the Firth of Thames - a fantastic place to spot both endemic and visiting birds.
Spend the day on a Kiwi Dundee eco-tour exploring the coastline and forest of the peninsula.
Drive south to Tongariro National Park where you will spend two nights in the Nightsky Cottage, a completely luxury eco-retreat.
Today is at leisure to hike around the National Park and enjoy the three volcanic mountains that make up Tongariro National Park.
Visit the Karori Wildlife sanctuary, a safe-haven for endangered native birds and other wildlife and/or take the historic cable car up to the botanical gardens
Board the Interislander ferry to Picton and stay at the historic Portage Resort in the Marlborough Sounds.
Spend the day hiking or biking around the Queen Charlotte Track.
Return to Picton, and drive to Kaikoura. In the afternoon enjoy a superb whale watching trip before hiking to your glass cabin that is completely immersed in nature.
Enjoy the day hiking around the Kaikoura Mountains and enjoy being in nature.

Drive up to Arthur’s Pass in the Southern Alps. Stay at Wilderness Lodge, which was set up to show that ecotourism can contribute to the economy and also protect the environment through nature conservation programmes.

Spend the day walking in this pristine region, either guided or unguided. The lodge owners have spent years working with the Department of Conservation to identify rare and endangered plants and birds, which have been reintroduced on to the land around the lodge. Return to Christchurch in the evening.
Drive to Dunedin, stopping at the interesting Moeraki Boulders on the way. Stay at the historic Fletcher Lodge.
Explore the stunning Otago Peninsula, where you can visit protected colonies of yellow-eyed and blue penguins, sea lions and fur seals, and the world’s only mainland albatross colony.

Drive to Invercargill and board a light aircraft to Stewart Island. You will be met by your local host and taken to your accommodation at the Stewart Island Lodge, set in native bush with abundant birdlife.
Spend the day exploring the primeval forests around Stewart Island. In the afternoon take a guided walk through the forest to spot the illusive and flightless kiwi bird.
Return to the mainland and drive to Te Anau. Stay at Te Anau Lodge, a former convent with a wealth of history and character.

Take a day trip to the glacial formed Milford Sound for a nature cruise, with highly knowledgeable on-board naturalists and geologists. You will also visit the fascinating underwater observatory, which due to the unique underwater environment of the Sound allows you to view precious corals, sea stars and fish which are usually only seen by divers.

Drive to magnificent Queenstown, where you will end your trip. Explore some true ‘Lord of the Rings’ country, visit historic gold-mining townships, or simply sit back and take in the stunning lake views before catching your onward flight home.

tourName: New Zealand 17 day tour
generalInfo:
From the volcanic landscapes of the North Island to the majestic snow-capped peaks of the South, New Zealand is a breathtaking playground of wilderness and wonder. Over 17 unforgettable days, we’ll take you on the ultimate adventure, combining the must-see highlights with thrilling off-the-beaten-path experiences. Step into the magic of Hobbiton, dive into the rich traditions of Maori culture, explore glowing underground caves, and soak up the energy of Wellington’s vibrant capital. Then, fly south for epic hikes through dramatic landscapes, cruise through mist-shrouded fjords, and feel the adrenaline rush of jet boating through jaw-dropping scenery—and that’s just the beginning!

Opt for the NZ Intro work add-on, and we'll also help you kickstart your adventure with all the essentials, including finding work in New Zealand. With an awesome group leader from the moment your trip starts, an instant group of friends to share your adventure, amazing accommodation and so much included. Get ready for the trip of a lifetime!


HIGHLIGHTS

- Explore the world-famous Waitomo glowworm caves by boat
- Tour the real Hobbiton film set and locations featured in The Lord Of The Rings and Hobbit trilogies
- Experience New Zealand’s incredible volcanic landscapes and thundering waterfalls
- Experience authentic Maori culture in a traditional Maori village
- Sail across Lake Taupo
- Discover New Zealand’s capital – Wellington
- Explore Aoraki/Mount Cook National Park
- Kayak on Lake Wanaka
- Experience the thrill of Queenstown
- Sail through the awe-inspiring beauty of Milford Sound
- Speed through rugged canyons on an exhilarating jet boat ride
- Get unlimited assistance securing a paid job in New Zealand with the NZ Intro work add-on

INCLUSIONS

16 nights accommodation
Waitomo glowworm caves boat tour
Hobbiton film set tour
Kerosene creek
Wai o Tapu
Maori experience
Lake Taupo sail
Huka Falls
Wellington city orientation
Te Papa Tongarewa Museum
Wellington Cable Car
Christchurch city orientation
Lake Tekapo hot pools
Mount John hike
Mount Cook / Aoraki National Park
Kayaking on Lake Wanaka
Queenstown city orientation
Milford Sound cruise
Jet boating on Lake Wakatipu
All transport
Meals as indicated on itinerary
Experienced group leader and local guides
24/7 assistance & support in New Zealand
Help with all onward travel after the trip
+ This tour is 100% carbon neutral!

INTRO WORK ADD ONS

Work Inclusions:
NZ bank account
IRD SIM card
Lifetime NZ Jobs membership
Unlimited job finding assistance

dayInfo.description: Arrive and Meet your Group – Kia ora! Landing in Auckland, we’ll meet you at our centrally located hostel to settle in. Tonight you’ll meet up with the rest of your travel crew and get excited for all the adventures yet to come travelling New Zealand!

Glowworm Caves & Hobbiton - Leaving Auckland, we’re off to discover the best of the beautiful North Island. Our first stop is Waitomo, home to the world- famous glowworm caves. We’ll explore this surreal, subterranean landscape by boat, watching in awe as the glowworms light up the darkness. Next we’re heading to Hobbiton, the real-life movie set featured in The Lord Of The Rings and Hobbit trilogies. After strolling through the enchanting village on a guided tour, we’ll enjoy a drink at the Green Dragon Inn before departing for Rotorua.

Explore Rotorua – First on the agenda is Kerosene Creek, a naturally heated hot spring where we can laze away the morning. Next is one of New Zealand’s most magnificent geothermal wonderlands – Wai o Tapu, featuring dramatic geysers & bubbling mud.

This morning, enjoy some free time to try exciting activities like zorbing or the skyline luge. In the evening we’ll visit the Mitai Maori village for an introduction to Maori culture — an experience as authentic as it gets!

Taupo Sail - Get your cameras out as we head to Taupo, a lakefront town right in the heart of the North. Tonight we’ve got something special lined up - a sail across the lake. The majestic scenery and the maori rock carvings will wow us.

Waterfalls & Adrenaline – This morning we’ll check out the epic Huka Falls, a spine-tingling torrent of icy water thundering down from the Waikato River. After witnessing the raw power of Mother Nature, you’ll then have some free time when you can do a skydive or bungee jump!

Travel to Wellington – Today, we’re off to New Zealand’s vibrant capital, Wellington! Immerse yourself in the city's lively atmosphere by visiting its cozy cafes, savouring mouthwatering dishes at delicious restaurants, or simply unwinding and soaking in the relaxed evening vibes.

Discover Wellington – Kick off your day with a city orientation tour, exploring the highlights of New Zealand’s capital! Ride the famous cable cars for panoramic views, then delve into the fascinating history and lively culture at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum—one of the world’s top museums.

Fly to Christchurch – After exploring the North Island, it’s time to head south! A quick included flight will bring you to Christchurch, where you’ll reunite with your travel crew and get ready for the exciting adventures that lie ahead.
Christchurch Orientation & Lake Tekapo – Explore the lively city of Christchurch, where history and culture come to life around every corner, before heading to the stunning beauty of Lake Tekapo!
Lake Tekapo – Today we’ll take a hike up Mt John where we’ll get 360-degree views of the Southern Alps before soaking our tired muscles in some hot pools.
This morning we'll make our way to Wanaka. This afternoon we’ll stretch our limbs hiking for unforgettable views of Aoraki/Mt Cook, the highest mountain in New Zealand.

Discover Wanaka - Today we’ll check out the highlights of Wanaka, including going kayaking on the stunning Lake Wanaka and discovering the famous Wanaka Tree. We’ll later hike up Mount Iron for stunning views of the local area including The Pisa range, Upper Clutha Basin and the mesmerising Southern Alps.
Today we’ll travel to the beautiful city of Queenstown. We'll have some time to explore this epic city.

Milford Sound Cruise - Leaving Queenstown, today we’re heading to the majestic Milford Sound. We’ll hop on a boat to cruise around the fjord, feeling tiny amongst sheer cliff faces, ancient forests, and plunging waterfalls.

Queenstown & Jet Boating – Today we’ll show you around stunning Queenstown with an orientation walk. The good news is that our first jolt of adrenaline isn’t far off, as this afternoon we’ll be zipping through Canyons on a jet boat going over 80 km/h. Tonight we’ll get together one last time for our farewell dinner.

Check Out – This morning your unforgettable 17 day adventure comes to an end. Check out and journey home, stay in Queenstown, or continue the next leg of your travels with the new friends you’ve made! Whatever your plans, we’ll be there to help every step of the way.

tourName: New Zealand 3 week holiday, self drive
generalInfo: See the best of New Zealand in three weeks taking in the thermal splendours of Rotorua on North Island and the majestic alpine scenery of Fiordland in the south, with some unforgettable experiences en route.

dayInfo.description: We greet you on arrival at the airport and take you to your hotel where you can relax before getting to know the ‘City of Sails’.

A great start to city sightseeing is to ascend the Sky Tower: a SkyWalk is optional! Nearby Queen Street is the main strip and you could end your day with a waterfront dinner in the new Wynyard Quarter.

Collect a rental vehicle and head south to Waitomo Glow Worm caves before being welcomed to a real New Zealand home. Your hosts are delighted to show off the farm, and share a home-cooked dinner with you before you enjoy a good night’s sleep.

From the Buried Village to Whakarewarewa, Te Puia and Waimangu: all fascinating attractions that blend the two aspects that make Rotorua a must: Maori culture and geothermal activity. We can also recommend an authentic Maori hangi for dinner!

On the road south, make time to see the Lady Knox Geyser at Wai O Tapu Geothermal Park. Stop in Taupo for lunch before entering Tongariro National Park, a starkly beautiful volcanic landscape. (Alternatively head east to the Art Deco town of Napier.)

Often described as the finest one day walk in New Zealand, the Tongariro Crossing is a full day traverse of the ‘saddle’ between Mts Tongariro and Ngauruhoe. Shorter walks are also possible. A round of golf on an all-weather course, or a soak in a natural hot pool are other options.

Travel through country towns to Wellington, still the ‘coolest little capital in the world’ thanks to its combination of location, architecture, café culture and laid-back lifestyle. Drop off your rental vehicle before a stroll through Civic Square to a Queens Wharf restaurant.
Board the Interislander ferry to cruise to South Island, boarding a coach in Picton for the transfer to Nelson, the sunniest town in New Zealand.

It is easy to gush about the beauty of Abel Tasman National Park! Golden beaches, turquoise water and pristine native bush combine to create a natural paradise you can explore by boat, kayak or on foot. We have plenty of tips for you.

Collect a rental vehicle and drive through the challenging Buller Gorge to Westport, with a stop for seal-spotting at Cape Foulwind. Follow the rugged coast to Punakaiki to see the weird blowholes at Dolomite Point.
Today your route takes you down the West Coast, through Greymouth, to Hokitika, keeping the Tasman sea on your right and the Southern Alps on your left.

Hokitika, once a gold rush town, is now a haven for craftspeople and a good place to buy pounamu (greenstone) carvings. Arrive in Franz Josef in time to see the glacier on a guided hike or helicopter trip: landing on the Tasman Glacier is an unforgettable experience!
Travel south through native rainforest, over mountain streams into the rugged beauty of the Haast Pass. Continue round the shores of glacial Hawea and Wanaka lakes to Wanaka township.

One of our favourite destinations, the snow-capped peaks, long river valleys and lush native forest are centred around the beautiful lake. There are ‘tramping’ opportunities for every experience level.
A jet boat trip or a waterfall climb are both guaranteed to set the pulses racing. In the evening, take a seat at Cinema Paradiso: they range from slouchy sofas to a modified Morris Minor!
Travel through Central Otago, around the shores of Lake Wakatipu to Te Anau, one of Fiordland’s most beautiful lakes. Round off the day with a lakeside stroll.

An early start for one of the world’s most scenic coach trips! Travelling through the National Park is integral to the Milford Sound experience. On arrival, a cruise on the Sound reveals vertiginous cliffs, cascading waterfalls and awesome Mitre Peak.
Drive to Queenstown, sometimes called 'The Switzerland of the Southern Hemisphere’ and superbly set on Lake Wakatipu.
So much to do, so little time! Stroll in well-kept gardens, cruise Lake Wakatipu or try an adrenalin activity like bungy jumping or an off-road 4X4 tour.
Drive through Mackenzie Country to Lake Pukaki and up to Mt Cook Village. Short walks to Kea Point or into the Hooker Valley offer wonderful mountain views. Descend to Twizel to overnight.

Make an early stop at the Church of the Good Shepherd, whose altar window frames Lake Tekapu. Cross the tussock plains, so evocative of sheep country, through Fairlie and Geraldine to arrive in Christchurch.

Following 2011’s earthquake, this Garden City is rebuilding, blending old (Botanic Gardens, River Avon and the Tram) with new (the Cardboard Cathedral, Container Mall and countless pop-up bars) to reclaim its place as the premier city of South Island.
Transfer to Christchurch Airport for your flight home, or ask us about dovetailing this itinerary with one of our Small Group Journeys to extend your time in New Zealand.

tourName: New Zealand 9 day tour
generalInfo:
From the bubbling volcanic wonders of Rotorua to the enchanting landscapes of real-life Hobbiton, New Zealand’s North Island is full of wilderness and adventure. Get ready to experience the island’s iconic highlights alongside thrilling off-the-beaten-path discoveries. Stroll through the magical Hobbiton film set, immerse yourself in the vibrant traditions of Maori culture, relax in natural thermal hot springs, explore mysterious underground caves, sail across the dazzling waters of Lake Taupo, uncover the charm of Wellington, and so much more!

Opt for the NZ Intro North work add-on, and we'll also help you kickstart your adventure with all the essentials, including finding work in New Zealand. With an awesome group leader from the moment your trip starts, an instant group of friends to share your adventure, amazing accommodation and so much included. Get ready for the trip of a lifetime!

HIGHLIGHTS
– Explore the world-famous Waitomo glowworm caves by boat
– Tour the real Hobbiton film set and locations featured in The Lord Of The Rings and Hobbit trilogies
– Experience New Zealand’s incredible volcanic landscapes and thundering waterfalls
– Experience authentic Maori culture in a traditional Maori village
– Sail across Lake Taupo
– Discover New Zealand’s capital – Wellington
– Get unlimited assistance securing a paid job in New Zealand with the NZ Intro North work add-on

tourName: New Zealand adventure holiday
placesVisited: Auckland, Tiri Tiri Matangi Reserve, Rotorua, Huka Falls, Tongariro National Park, Tongariro Crossing, Wellington, Cook Strait, Marlborough, Abel Tasman National Park, Motueka, Buller River, Punakaiki, Fox Glacier, Okaroto, Wanaka, Matukitiki, Milford Sound, Inner Sound, Queenstown, Mount Cook National Park, Christchurch, Canterbury Plains, Optional activities include a scenic flight over Tongariro Crossing, helicopter ride and walk over Fox Glacier and bungee jumping in Queenstown
generalInfo:
Starting in Auckland, travelling through the North Island and snaking down through the South Island in almost a full loop, this three-week small-group guided holiday reveals New Zealand in all its glorious variety. By far the best way to appreciate its natural wonders is on foot and by boat so this is an active trip, which maximises the time spent in the outdoors. You’ll need a good level of fitness to make the most of the jam-packed itinerary. There are five half days and three full days of walking through beautiful national parks, including hiking on the Fox Glacier and tackling the Tongariro Crossing. Dubbed one of the greatest one-day walks in New Zealand, this route goes through rugged volcanic desert, past craters and glacial valleys with incredible views.

You won’t just be walking though. Cruising around Milford Sound searching for dolphins and seals and jetboating through Mount Aspiring National Park are two standout activities. During your time here, you’ll also come to understand New Zealand’s unique heritage, meeting Maoris in Rotorua and visiting the New Zealand National Museum in Wellington. Sleep soundly after all that fresh air in comfortable hotels and lodges, most with ensuite facilities, and enjoy a single night on a cruise boat, too.

dayInfo.description: The day is free to relax and recover from the flight. If you’re arriving into Auckland Airport today, you can arrange a free arrival (shared shuttle) transfer from the airport to the hotel – see the Joining Instructions for more information. Auckland is a beautiful city and worthy of time to explore. The nearby Viaduct restaurants are an ideal means of overcoming the last of the jetlag. If you’re feeling lucky, visit the SkyCity casino and entertainment tower for one of those lunches you just don’t forget. Please meet at the start hotel at 6pm for a full briefing with your leader. Accommodation: Copthorne Auckland City Hotel (or similar)

Auckland is the City of Sails, so what better way to start your trip than to cruise across the Hauraki Gulf to beautiful Rangitoto Island? At 600 years’ old, it is actually the youngest volcano in New Zealand. The island has undergone a significant restoration programme and is entirely pest-free, which encourages the native flora and fauna to thrive. We walk through lava fields and forests to the island summit (850ft/259m) for stunning panoramic views of Auckland and the Hauraki Gulf. Please note: Occasionally, access is temporarily and unexpectedly denied to various islands off the Auckland coast including Rangitoto due to cultural considerations. In this case, we respect the local Maori wishes and try to visit an alternative island if possible. Accommodation: Copthorne Auckland City Hotel (or similar)

Leaving the city, we head south to Rotorua (approximately 3hr 30min drive). On arrival, we stretch our legs with a hike around a redwood forest followed by an afternoon at leisure in town or an optional hike at Blue Lake. The evening highlight is a visit to a marae (ceremonial ground). Our Maori hosts welcome us in their traditional manner before entertaining us with a concert and hangi (traditional meal). Accommodation: Sudima Hotel Lake Rotorua (or similar)

We explore one of the most colourful thermal areas in New Zealand with boiling mud pools, hot streams and silica terraces. The natural wonders that first attracted the Maori in the 14th century, and later the Europeans, still draw large numbers of tourists every year. Rotorua is a unique natural wonder and a must-see destination. Leaving Rotorua, we drive south (approximately three hours) to Tongariro National Park. On the way, we visit the steaming Wai-O-Tapu geothermal valley and impressive Huka Falls. Accommodation: The Park Hotel (or similar)

We wake up in the heart of Tongariro National Park, the oldest national park in New Zealand and a dual World Heritage area. This status recognises the important Maori cultural and spiritual associations plus its outstanding volcanic features. If you’re physically fit and well equipped, there is the option of walking the Tongariro Alpine Crossing: one of the greatest one-day walks in New Zealand. Provided the weather is kind, the rugged volcanic desert, craters and glacial valleys combine with incredible views to make this a day to remember. The crossing should not be underestimated and there are several steep sections where the loose surface can make it tough going, so come well-prepared. The crossing can take seven to eight hours depending on walking ability. There is a return shuttle service – 55 New Zealand dollars (US$32) per person – from your hotel to the start and finish of the crossing. Your leader provides you with information about the walk and can advise you on the fitness and equipment required. If you are intending to do the crossing, please bring sturdy walking shoes/boots, a suitable backpack, wind- and waterproof jacket and a warm hat. Distance: 12mi (19.4km); ascent: 2,510ft (765m); descent: 3,691ft (1,125m); total time: approximately seven to eight hours Alternatively, there are several other options available to experience the wonders of this unique environment. These include the Taranaki Falls walk, one of the best short walks in the park. This easy loop takes in a variety of volcanic landforms, forest and native shrubland along with excellent volcano and waterfall views. Distance: 3.7mi (6km); ascent: 377ft (115m); descent: 377ft (115m); total time: approximately 2hr 30min Other options include a visit to the park conservation centre, a trip up Mount Ruapehu on the Sky Waka gondola with a short walk to the viewing platform, a visit to the Tokaanu Thermal Pools or a unique rafting experience including the opportunity to help with conservation efforts for an endangered native duck. Your leader will discuss the options and additional costs for the day. Based on the weather and interest of the group, your leader can join the majority of the group in their chosen activity. Where external transfers or the services of an external provider are required, then additional costs are payable on the day. Please also see the Optional Excursions section of the Trip Notes for further details. Accommodation: The Park Hotel (or similar)

Relax following yesterday’s free day of exploring Tongariro National Park as we drive (approximately five hours) south to Wellington. Continue across the Rangitikei and Manawatu Plains and down the Kapiti Coast to Wellington. On Wellington waterfront is Te Papa, the NZ National Museum, which we can explore in the afternoon along with the beautiful botanic gardens and cable car and enjoy the exciting nightlife of the capital city. Accommodation: James Cook Hotel Grand Chancellor (or similar)

After an early breakfast, we board the ferry and leave the North Island as we cross the Cook Strait, passing the Marlborough Sounds with 932mi (1,500km) of beautiful coastline. From Picton, we have a 1hr 30min drive to Nelson where we can take time out to explore the city and a chance to stretch our legs with a short walk to the geographical centre of New Zealand. After, we drive to the small town of Motueka (approximately one hour) on the edge of Abel Tasman National Park, home to idyllic gold-sand beaches and forests. Accommodation: Nautilus Lodge Motel or Motueka Garden Motel (or similar)

We have a 25-minute transfer to the village of Marahau, where a morning coastal walk takes us through beautiful beaches and coastal vegetation. The path is well maintained and the walk takes approximately three to four hours. We meet our sailing boat at Anchorage Bay, providing our return to Marahau and time to relax and dine out in Motueka. (Depending on tides, sometimes the sailing trip is completed first). Please note, today your leader has a guide-free day. Instead, you are accompanied by a local guide on the coastal walk who has expert local knowledge. Return transfers from Motueka are provided. Accommodation: Nautilus Lodge Motel or Motueka Garden Motel (or similar)

Our departure from Abel Tasman National Park is followed by a scenic drive down the mighty Buller River. After a short stop at Cape Foulwind to see the seal colony, we stop at Punakaiki, home of the famous Pancake Rocks. If the tide is up, the ground can physically shake and water spurts from the blowholes and fissures that dot the coastline (drive time approximately 5 hours). We then take a short transfer (approx. 40 minutes) onto the coastal town of Greymouth, considered the heart of the South Island's west coast where we stay overnight. Accommodation: Copthorne Hotel Greymouth or The Ashley Hotel (or similar)

Passing through areas of lush forests, we continue south down the beautiful west coast. We drive onto the small lagoon-side village of Okarito, home of the rare kotuku (white heron). On offer here is optional kayaking where we float in on the incoming tide and explore the bush-clad waterways seeking out the abundant bird life here. Those looking to stretch their legs can hike to the nearby trig station (approximately 1hr 30min) for spectacular views over the Southern Alps. Later, we continue the short drive through to Fox township. Depending on time, you may have an opportunity to hike to the lookout for the Franz Josef Glacier. Accommodation: Heartland Hotel Fox Glacier (or similar)

After breakfast, we backtrack to the township of Franz Josef. From here, we go for a walk to the lookout point for the glacier (if not completed the day before). After, we drive on and stroll around the reflective Lake Matheson, a photographer’s dream. We then continue south along bush-clad roads and past the dramatic coastline with its wild windswept beaches to the settlement of Haast. Turning inland, we climb over Haast Pass, the southernmost crossing of the Southern Alps, which forms the boundary between Westland and Otago. From here, the tussock lands of the eastern slopes merge with beech forests. We travel through to Wanaka, home for the next two nights. Lake Matheson Loop: Distance: 1.6mi (2.6km); ascent: 138ft (42m); descent: 138ft (42m); total time: approximately 1hr 30min Fox Glacier Valley Walkway: Distance: 1.6mi (2.6km); ascent: 223ft (68m); descent: 226ft (69m); total time: approximately one hour Accommodation: Aspiring Lodge Motel (or similar)

In the morning, we head into Mount Aspiring National Park for an exciting jetboat ride along the braided rivers leading into the park. Jetboating was invented in NZ as a means to negotiate the shallow braided rivers that we use to access a track leading to a hike into the cirque surrounded by huge mountain walls. Back at our coach, we eat our picnic lunch before driving onto our three-hour hike at beautiful Diamond Lake, which provides stunning views of the river delta and the landscape. Matukituki Valley: Distance: 1.3mi (2.2km); ascent: 95ft (29m); descent: 95ft (29m); total time: one hour Diamond Lake and Rocky Mountain Circuit: Distance: 4.4mi (7.1km); ascent: 1,434ft (437m); descent: 1,417ft (432m); total time: approximately two to three hours Accommodation: Aspiring Lodge Motel (or similar)

From Wanaka, we depart early heading for Te Anau and then into Eglington Valley, enjoying a series of short walks in the spectacular Milford region and then into Milford Sound itself where we join our floating accommodation for the night. The Milford Mariner boat, which has two-bed cabins with private bathrooms, allows us to stay overnight amid dolphins and mighty peaks towering above the fjord. Please pack a small overnight bag for the boat; you are reunited with your main luggage tomorrow after disembarking. Walk profile: Various short walk options on Milford Road of up to one hour depending on group fitness, weather and time Accommodation: Milford Mariner

After an early breakfast, we cruise the inner sound again searching for dolphins and seals before disembarking and retracing our tracks to The Divide and the start of the Routeburn Track. Here we take a three-hour walk to Key Summit for spectacular views. After this hike, we drive via Te Anau (approximately four hours) onto Queenstown, where we stay for the next two nights. Accommodation: Heartland Hotel Queenstown (or similar)

Today is free to enjoy the scenic delights of this world-famous destination! There are numerous activities on offer, which your leader can advise about locally. Or you may just prefer to spend the day shopping or relaxing. Today your leader has a guide-free day but they can advise on how best to spend your free day in Queenstown. Accommodation: Heartland Hotel Queenstown (or similar)

Travel through the barren Kawarau Gorge where large amounts of gold were dredged at the turn of the century. Drive over Lindis Pass to the tussock-covered plains of the Mackenzie Basin and into Mount Cook National Park (approximately four hours). Beneath the highest peak in NZ, we walk into Hooker Valley, which has crashing glaciers and glacial lakes. By early evening, we reach our accommodation and watch the spectacular view from the warmth of the restaurant. Accommodation: Aoraki Mount Cook Alpine Lodge/Hermitage Mount Cook (or similar)

After breakfast, we drive to Christchurch via the Canterbury Plains. After the devastating earthquakes of 2010/11, Christchurch is undergoing a major rebuild, unrivalled in the world. The afternoon is free for you to explore this city, beautiful gardens and Hagley Park followed by an optional final group dinner. Accommodation: Scenic Hotel Cotswold Christchurch (or similar)

The trip finishes after breakfast and checkout from the hotel. A free departure transfer by taxi from the hotel to Christchurch Airport is included but it must be booked at least one month before departure.

tourName: New Zealand classic self drive tour
placesVisited: Auckland, Waikato, Hobbiton, Rotorua, Wellington, Cross the Cook Strait to South Island, Whale watching in Kaikoura, Christchurch, Mount Cook National Park, Dunedin, Otago Peninsula, Fjordland, Cruise on Milford Sound, Queenstown, West Coast and glacier country, Stay in locally run bed and breakfasts, lodges and hotels
generalInfo:
North Island or South Island? You can explore both on this 21-day New Zealand fly drive tour which gets you to all the biggest sights, from Tongariro National Park in North Island to South Island’s glaciers.

Driving is the simplest way to reach the most scenic New Zealand locations and gives you the freedom to stop at lesser visited sights in between: that quirky roadside café, or that layby with the beautiful sea view. Twenty nights gives you an unhurried and immersive New Zealand experience.

This trip starts with North Island. You’ll pick up your car in Auckland before heading south via ‘Hobbiton’ – the film set from Lord of the Rings – in Waikato to Rotorua, and then on to Wellington. You’ll cross to South Island on the Cook Strait to Picton and then drive towards Christchurch, Queenstown and ‘glacier country’.

Exploring Maori culture is a must whilst you’re here, and there are plenty of ways to do so, whether you visit the cultural centre at Rotorua or enjoy a hangi feast, which includes dishes prepared in an earth oven – a slow cooking process that makes hearty meals out of ingredients like lamb, beef, sweet potatoes (kumara) and vegetables.

Wildlife is a massive highlight – in more ways than one. You can go whale watching at Kaikoura and watch these giants made weightless by the waves. A nighttime wildlife sanctuary tour will show you New Zealand’s more diminutive treasures, like a little spotted kiwi or hundreds of glow worms.

With all its wonderful wildlife, New Zealand is an ecologically minded country, making a responsible holiday here a natural fit. This New Zealand fly drive holiday makes use of the country’s extensive network of family-run bed and breakfasts to give you an authentic experience. These local businesses are doing their own bit to help with biodiversity on the islands, whether that’s by replanting native trees or creating wilderness areas on their properties; by staying with these inspiring hosts you can help support these endeavours.

dayInfo.description: Arrive into Auckland City Accommodation: Hotel Grand Chancellor Auckland City
Explore Auckland the 'City of Sails' Accommodation: Hotel Grand Chancellor Auckland City Meals included: Breakfast
Drive south through the rich fertile farmland of the Waikato and maybe stop at Hobbiton Village on your way to Rotorua Accommodation: Distinction Rotorua Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Your day in Rotorua could be spent discovering Maori culture or thrilling adventure rides Accommodation: Distinction Rotorua Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Today is filled with fantastic scenery including Lake Taupo, the Desert Road and the Kapiti Coastline as you approach Wellington Accommodation: Hotel Ibis Wellington Meals included: Breakfast
Today is free to explore the quirky city of Wellington including its cafes and great museums Accommodation: Hotel Ibis Wellington Meals included: Breakfast

Today you'll cross the Cook Strait on the Interislander Ferry. Approaching Picton you'll cruise through the spectacular Marlborough Sounds Accommodation: Picton Yacht Club Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Drive south along the beautiful coast highway to the seaside town of Kaikoura Accommodation: The White Morph, Kaikoura Meals included: Breakfast
Spend the morning in Kaikoura before you drive through North Canterbury countryside to reach today's destination of Christchurch Accommodation: Heartland Hotel Cotswold Meals included: Breakfast
Explore the evolving city of Christchurch, or maybe take a day trip to Akaroa Accommodation: Heartland Hotel Cotswold Meals included: Breakfast
Today you'll enjoy a scenic drive through Canterbury and the MacKenzie Country Accommodation: Hermitage Hotel Room Mount Cook View Meals included: Breakfast
Leaving the MacKenzie Country you'll follow the Waitaki River to the coast, where you'll turn south for Dunedin Accommodation: Dunedin Leisure Lodge – A Distinction Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Explore Dunedin and the Otago Peninsula Accommodation: Dunedin Leisure Lodge – A Distinction Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Travel through the rich farmland of South Otago and Southland to reach Te Anau, gateway to Fiordland Accommodation: Distinction Luxmore Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Today you'll journey on the magnificent Milford Road to Milford Sound for your cruise, then back to Te Anau Accommodation: Distinction Luxmore Hotel Meals included: Breakfast, Lunch
Travel through rolling Southland countryside then follow Lake Wakatipu to Queenstown Accommodation: Copthorne Hotel & Apartments Queenstown Lakeview Meals included: Breakfast, Speciality Dinner
Explore Queenstown and try one of the many activities on offer in this fun town Accommodation: Copthorne Hotel & Apartments Queenstown Lakeview Meals included: Breakfast
Take the Crown Range Road to Wanaka before travelling the spectacular Haast Pass to the West Coast Accommodation: High Peaks Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Explore Fox Glacier and surrounds Accommodation: High Peaks Hotel Meals included: Breakfast
Drive north along the stunning West Coast Road and take the TranzAlpine train to Christchurch Accommodation: Heartland Hotel Cotswold Meals included: Breakfast
Depart Christchurch today.

tourName: New Zealand cultural holiday
generalInfo:
This tailor made New Zealand holiday will introduce you to the very best of the country, with a stopover in Fiji thrown in for good measure. New Zealand has an incredible amount of variety - dramatic scenery, plentiful wildlife and a rich history and culture. This itinerary will give you a real feel for both the landscape and its people.

You’ll be presented with incredible beauty throughout your trip, from deserted sandy beaches, to wild mountain ranges, to untrammelled native forest, to spectacular geothermal activity.
