Upon arrival be ready to enter the meetinghouse with a friendly greeting with the chief. He presses his nose to yours to show that you are welcomed as more than a guest, but as a new family member, into the tribe’s home. The carvings on the façade of the meetinghouse resemble spirits; smooth wood is chiseled into detailed faces with tongues sticking out, eyes bulging out, and geometric tattoos standing out. The scent of polished wood gives way to the slow roasting of lamb and pheasant. You can almost hear the sizzle of the potatoes as they cook in the traditional manner, dug into the earth in a large hole stuffed with hot coals. The concert begins with tribal chants similar to those that stem from its Polynesian roots; however, the melodic sounds soon end. The Maori warriors enter with frayed grass skirts, ta moko, traditional body art, decorating their shoulders and faces. The drums pulse through your bones. The warriors slap their chests and scream into the night. They bulge their eyes and stick out their tongues like the craved sprits on meetinghouse’s façade. Their war cry beats thick in the air and you have witnessed the sensational haka . After the concert’s end you will return to your hotel; whether you prefer rural charm, urban opulence, or luxurious seclusion, there is no shortage of accommodation to fit your tastes.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua - The Best’s Volcano
dayInfo.description: Wake up to the excitement of coming adventures as you take the day to explore Rotorua and its surroundings. Being your day with a unique and thrilling scenic helicopter flight to Mokoia, an active volcanic crater. The island is home to a plethora of endangered birds, including the coarse-haired kiwi for which New Zealand is known. Mokoia is filled with Maori traditions and myths. The lush green of the island is brought about by the volcanic soil which is rich in nutrients. The surrounding water is almost indescribably blue and serene. Hover around the rugged terrain of White Island where the main crater is situated. At various times of the day you can see puffs of steam rising from the crater. Wind around the steaming cliffs of the thermal valley where you can also see the iridescent glow of the colored pools of the thermal reserve before setting back down to earth. Your best of adventures continue on a 4X4 journey through the dense and stunning landscapes that surround Rotorua. The roar of the vehicle hums beneath you as the dense forest begins to open up. Branches brush against the jeep. Water splashes around you. You can hear the thundering waterfalls in the distance as you rumble along the unpaved path to see the outskirts of the city, beyond the Cultural Capital and into the heart of nature. The landscape rolls and the trees are full, until the world opens up into a quiet plane where you can see the mountains far in the distance.

dayInfo.title: Napier - The Best Art Deco
dayInfo.description: Today you will leave the Cultural Capital behind you as you make your way to Napier, stopping in the beautiful city of Lake Taupo along the way. Circle around New Zealand’s largest lake, where the water reflects the surrounding mountains in perfect clarity. Take the opportunity to visit the jade waters of Huka Falls. For a fabulous rush and fantastic scenery, take a jet-boat ride along the thundering river, where the cool wind rushes through your hair and the crisp mist of the water splashes your face. You can also take an easy hike to the falls; you can stand on the bridge and watch the colorful water thunder over the rocks as you watch the jet-boat speed through the river in the distance. Whether you choose to linger around Taupo, rush through the river on the jet-boat, or enjoy the scenic drive, you will make your way to the region of Hawkes Bay and to the kaleidoscope colors of the Art Deco Capital, Napier.

dayInfo.title: Napier - The Best of Art Deco
dayInfo.description: The colors and vibrancy of Napier and Hawkes Bay are yours to explore. From the city streets to the outlying vineyards, there is plenty to see, plenty to taste, and plenty to do. Stroll along the streets of the city and see the expanse of Art Deco architecture that decorates the city in a virtual palette of colors. The bricklayer streets sparkle in the sunlight. The energy of the city is as vivacious as the colors, caught in the roaring vibrancy of the Art Deco movement that is less than a tradition and more of a way of life. Leave the colors of the city behind for a moment to experience the luxurious flavors of the region. A visit to the Craggy Range Vineyard gives you first-hand experience of the diverse landscapes of New Zealand and how those landscapes drastically change the flavors of vines and food, whether through tiny variations in temperature or by soil type. Sit along the edge of the vineyard where you can hear the crash of the ocean along the rocky shores. The scent of fresh grass and growing vines fills the air. Swirl the Shiraz around your glass and see the deep and dark purple hue, the sweet aromas of blackberries combine with hints of cocoa and freshly cracked black pepper. The refreshing acidity of the wine brings you back to the expansive Art Deco streets of Napier where you don’t have to ask for the best to know that you are getting the best.

dayInfo.title: Wellington - The Best Never Substitutes
dayInfo.description: Today you will depart the colorful and delicious town of Napier, making your way to the capital of New Zealand, Wellington. Along the way you will pass through the charming and beautiful town of Martinborough. The town contains a picturesque village square immersed in heritage buildings. The Victorian architecture lines the streets with encompassing balconies offering a view that wraps around the street corners. The Martinborough countryside is draped with vineyards that stretch along the valley and into the foothills, giving the region a diverse range of wine varietals and flavors. For a unique taste of the Martinborough pay a visit to Molive Gold, where their distinctive production of late harvested extra virgin olive oil results in a mellow and smooth taste. Continue on to Wellington where the sun glistens along the bay and invites you in. The city sits between the foothills of Mount Victoria and the cool waters of the Cook Straight. The red trolley rolls through the city, up the lush mountainside, and into the suburban gardens. For a decadent treat of New Zealand flavors visit Boulcott Street Bistro. The scent of smoky braised lamb drifts from the kitchen. The gentle spice of the crushed minted peas awakens your taste buds, and the slight crunch of the herb polenta gives you that satisfying texture assuring you it is the best lamb you’ve ever had.

dayInfo.title: Blenheim - The North to the South’s Best
dayInfo.description: The sun rises over Wellington and brings the colorful morning along with it. The buildings sparkle in the morning sun, the grass of Mount Victoria glistens, and the water laps calmly at the city’s shores. It is the perfect time to visit Te Papa, the National Museum of New Zealand. The quiet solitude of the museum brings with it the collective weight of the country’s various cultures, from the indigenous Maori to the European settlers, and the largest population of Polynesians outside of the Pacific Islands themselves. The balance of Te Papa lies in its ability to inform visitors about the diverse history of the North and South Island’s people, from the land’s origins to the country’s origins, sometimes proud and other times questionable, but always unbiased and informative. Board the Cook Straight Ferry and cruise along one of the most beautiful ferry rides in the world. The mountains of the surrounding bay recede into the distance. The open water is filled with sunlight and a cool breeze. The lush scenery of the South Island comes closer until you dock in the tiny town of Picton and make your way to Blenheim, the sunniest town in New Zealand. The city sits besides rolling hills and vast vineyards in the stunning Marlborough Region. Filled with large fountains stretching through the opulent parks, Blenheim feels more like a town in the countryside than a bustling city. Orchards are brimming with ripe apples and vineyards are chockfull of grapes ready for harvest. The scent of fresh citrus fills the city streets and invites you in.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - A Vineyard’s Best
dayInfo.description: Today you will depart from the lovely city of Blenheim and visit the Brancott Estate Vineyard. Marlborough is considered New Zealand’s most famous wine region and Brancott Estate is at the heart of Marlborough’s best. The ranch style building sits between the vineyards as they expand across the hills giving an orange and green tinge to the day. The cool, sunny climate and young soil help create some of the most distinctive Sauvignon Blanc. The wine has the delicate sweetness of ripe fruit and citrus giving it a crisp freshness. Stay and taste the luxurious pairing of the Sauvignon Blanc with the barbecued prawns. The simple citrus zest of the prawns makes the fruity bite of the wine pop. Continue on to Christchurch, filled with cobblestone-paved streets at its center, and the sound of the Avon River meandering around the parks and streets. Known as the Garden City, you will easily see the pristine parks decorating the city and bursting with the vibrant colors of blossomed lupines, daisies, roses, and trees. Punters glide down the river in romantic embraces and with blissful smiles as the river opens the expanse of the city to the aquatic explorers. The hum of the trolley car fills the city center. The stone facades of the Victorian past remain in the spired cathedral and the vast façade of the college. Whether strolling through the gardens or the streets of Christchurch, the best of the city is offered to you in plain view.

dayInfo.title: Aoraki - The Best of the Best
dayInfo.description: Depart the Garden City and make your way southward. The Canterbury Plains are vibrant green-sectioned farmland. The white wool of sheep stands against the lively colors of the plain that stretch along the foothills of the mountains. Stop and admire the exceptional beauty of Lake Tekapo. The snowcapped mountains in the background frame the turquoise lake where purple lupines blossom and sweep across the bank. Once in Aoraki you will enjoy an exceptional dinner at the award-winning Panorama Restaurant located in the Hermitage Hotel. The hotel is located at the base of the Southern Alps where, through the panoramic window, you can see the majestic mountain range lifting into the sky as the various mountaintops spread into the distance.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - For the Best View
dayInfo.description: Eventually you will leave the majesty of Aoraki behind, but, weather permitting, you should never pass up the chance to explore the Tasman Glacier. Board the inflatable raft with your knowledgeable guide and drift along the serene lake that is fed by opulent glacial waters. The snow is an untouched white along the shores until you reach the base of the Tasman Glacier. The bluish-white covers the textured surface and stretches between mountains as Mount Cook, the tallest mountain in the Southern Hemisphere, lingers over the range. Continue on your way to Queenstown with a stop along the fabulous Lindis Pass, where the colors change with the seasons. The Southern Alps fill the horizon as the orange plains shine in the autumn, the gold shimmering in the spring. Enjoy a stop at Mrs. Jones’ Fruit Orchard and sample the luscious fresh fruits. The kiwis are a vibrant green with a juicy citrus and the cherries offer a fragrant and satisfying scent. The almonds and nut varieties are worth the stop alone. Once in Queenstown you can relax in the comfort of the alpine city’s treats. The mix of village charm and city luxury is inherent in the city’s beauty, nuzzled between the foothills of Bob’s Peak and the shores of Lake Wakatipu. While in Queenstown you can be certain that every decision you make is the best decision.

dayInfo.title: Milford Sound - The Best Sound
dayInfo.description: Travel into the depths of Fiordland National Park to experience the exceptional sights of Milford Sound. Board the famous Red Boat Cruise and enjoy the unforgettable experience of cruising through one of New Zealand’s most famous fiords. The water is calm and serene year-round, where dolphins swim in the boat’s wake and jump through the crisp and cool air. Waterfalls tumble down the mountainsides and crash into the sound, the cool mist rising into the sky. The scent of pure nature fills the fiord. You can hear the squawk of penguins in the distance and see them waddling along the boulder-filled shores. The majestic nature of Milford Sound is inherent in both its breathtaking beauty and continuous untouched serenity. Its magnitude swallows you whole and the best part is, you might never want to leave.

dayInfo.title: Milford Sounds - The Best Never Ends
dayInfo.description: Today your tour through the best of New Zealand will come to an end; however, there is always more to experience and more time to find the best of what New Zealand has to offer. The most southern region of the country offers a variety of delicious Pinot Noirs in an area filled with ineffable beauty. The Remarkables stand tall above the sunken valleys where vineyards thrive. The Mata-Au Pinot from Chard Farm offers you a reminder of the luscious region with a nose of floral spice and dried herbs, like the surrounding trees. The balance comes from an herbal, silky tannic structure and the quality length of the finish, a perfect metaphor for your adventure through New Zealand. Why let the best slip away by ending your vacation now? One of the luxuries of a customizable tour is your ability to stay longer. Extend your experience and give yourself more days to explore the rest of the best that New Zealand has on offer. See more of Queenstown’s surrounding attractions, or wander away off of your current path and into the wide selection of great places to stay. Listen, browse, and discover local offerings while the rest of your itinerary comes to life. Related Information: If you enjoy wine and breath-taking scenery, then this itinerary is for you in New Zealand. With an off road adventure, a helicopter ride, and a cruise included into the trip, it’ll surely impress each traveler for the rest of his or her life in this once in a lifetime excursion. If you choose to stay over in Queenstown and see more of the surrounding attractions, there is a wide selection of great places to stay and be sure to browse through local offerings here, while you plan the rest of your itinerary. You may find the travel reviews for New Zealand section helpful.

tourName: 14-Day Romantic Adventure to Australia & New Zealand
placesVisited: Waiheke Island, Coromandel Peninsula, Queenstown, Milford Sound, Sydney, Hunter Valley, Uluru
generalInfo: Handcrafted for exclusivity and privacy, this exciting two-week adventure through New Zealand and Australia are all about the unique places where romance can thrive. Stars shimmer as you sit in silence, fjords inspire, and vineyards exude indulgence. Islands create magic, and from a helicopter, you can venture where other travelers do not. From tropical islands to city extravagance and the big red desert, prepare yourselves to stroll hand in hand in the Southern Hemisphere’s remarkable landscapes.

dayInfo.title: Waiheke Island – Beachside Retreat
dayInfo.description: After arriving at Auckland’s international airport, you will be transferred to the harbor on the short ferry journey. This little extra journey will be really worth it, even after a long flight to New Zealand. You will arrive in Waiheke, where you will relax above a golden bay. You may notice the lack of footprints in the sand, which may provide you with a sense of indulgence and seclusion. Most flights to New Zealand land in the morning, which will give you an entire first day to relax and become acclimated. Early check-in will be arranged at your luxurious accommodation, and afterward, you can just walk down some steps to the beach.

dayInfo.title: Waiheke Island – Remote Island Beaches
dayInfo.description: Today, you can wake up at your own pace and enjoy the ocean breeze. You can order breakfast to your balcony and then go back to bed if you want. On this vacation, it is about how you feel, especially at the lodges and hotels that have been handpicked for their luxury. Luscious vineyards carpet the interior of the island, and they are all connected by walking trails, so it will be easy to indulge in tastings at up to ten different vineyards. The fjords and mountains will come later, but for now, you can escape into tropical island bliss and completely ease into your vacation.

dayInfo.title: Coromandel Peninsula – Romantic Escapism
dayInfo.description: From Waiheke, you will travel in style because a helicopter will fly you across the South Pacific to the Coromandel Peninsula, which is a destination of raw, natural splendor and seclusion. For these two days, you can snuggle at the lodge and indulge in a stroll to a very quiet beach. There will be fine dining with an ocean breeze and the sense of privacy that is demanded by all couples who are seeking romance. Cocktails can flow on the balcony, and you can spend two days doing nothing at all if you choose. However, Coromandel is also a place to celebrate New Zealand’s great outdoors, and a personal concierge can organize a variety of activities for you.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Beneath Snowy Mountains
dayInfo.description: Rather than staying in Queenstown, you will be tucked away at a private lodge along the lakeshore, which will be close enough to visit Queenstown’s restaurants and attractions. Your lodge will also evoke a wilderness feel. After your flight from Auckland, you will have an afternoon to try one of Queenstown’s exciting activities. One option will be a private boat cruise on the lake, and a guide can lead you to the Central Otago vineyards for some decadent tasting and fine cuisine. If you are feeling adventurous, then you can run off Bob’s Peak on a tandem paraglide or experience the buzz of a jet boat. This is a spectacular setting, and you can enjoy a wonderful day of sinking your senses into the landscapes.

dayInfo.title: Milford Sound – Overnight Cruise on the Fjord
dayInfo.description: After a road transfer from Queenstown, you will spend the afternoon on a luxurious boat cruise through Milford Sound. You will have the chance to go kayaking on the fjord, which will provide you with amazing close-ups of the seals and dolphins. The best part of this experience is that when the other boats return to harbor, yours will stay out in the wilderness. Milford Sound is a majestic place, and it was also New Zealand’s entry in the world's seven wonders competition. It is most special just before dusk, which is when there are no other boats, and you can bask privately in all its iconicity. Dinner will be served, and you will spend the night in the heart of Fiordland, tucked into a fjord listening to the wind singing through the night.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown �– Helicopter to Glaciers
dayInfo.description: The premier highlight of an overnight cruise is that you can wake up in the fjord, experience how it emerges, and admire all its sensual beauty. After a morning that can involve kayaking with dolphins, you will return to the harbor and venture back to Queenstown. By flying over Fiordland in a helicopter, you will enjoy spectacular views over the UNESCO World Heritage Site. Fjords are separated by snowy mountains and glaciers, and the landscape captures the essence of untouched wilderness. Your first stop will be on a glacier, where ice sculptures will form a natural art gallery, and you can really feel Fiordland’s vastness.

dayInfo.title: Sydney – Cruising the Parramatta
dayInfo.description: Today, you will be in the midst of fine dining restaurants, where only those in the know can get a table, and sunset cocktails at opulent beach clubs. With two days in the city, you can indulge in city pleasures, and a guide will arrange everything for your interests and mood. It will begin with a private cruise along the Parramatta River in the late afternoon, and you will glide under the bridge and alongside the shimmering sails of the Sydney Opera House. Food and drinks will be served on the deck, and you will be treated to the sunset over the Blue Mountains and Sydney.

dayInfo.title: Sydney – In an Iconic City
dayInfo.description: This full day in Sydney will be deliberately left free, so you can customize it to your interests. Australia’s most iconic destination has too much for a single day of discovery, and every couple can find something different here, from craft markets to famous beach bars and encounters with kangaroos to a night at the opera house. Your guide will tailor a day around how you feel, whether that is one on one with a koala or dining among the cobblestone lanes of The Rocks. You should try not to do too much in Sydney because you will miss out on why the city is special. You should take it slow and go with the flow.

dayInfo.title: Hunter Valley – Hot Air Balloon Ride
dayInfo.description: Traveling from Sydney to Hunter Valley will be so easy by helicopter as you swap an urban landscape for rolling hills and endless vines. You will be staying on a vineyard that is hidden away in a place where privacy is paramount. Today, the helicopter will touch down to a boutique brunch and wine tasting at one of the Hunter Valley’s most celebrated vineyards. From here, you can stop at another one to three wine farms before cuddling up at your vineyard retreat for a night of solitude. Day 11 will begin with a hot air balloon flight over the valley with shards of golden light bringing the Hunter Valley out of the shadow and a bottle of sparkling wine. You will have a full day to discover more of the region’s vineyards, and a local guide can arrange tastings with a winemaker or cellar-master.

dayInfo.title: Uluru – Beneath the Southern Sky
dayInfo.description: Today, you will venture out into the desert, which is the great, red landscape that covers most of Australia. After a flight from Sydney to Uluru, you will be transferred to an intimate desert camp that is well away from the main Uluru crowds. You can stop, breathe, and inhale the silence. This is the wilderness, and there will be nothing here but the two of you. The camp provides luxury in the wilderness, and the premium is on space. After you spend an afternoon at the fabulous domes of Kata Tjuta, admiring how the desert’s color is always ephemeral, you will have a night of pure seclusion beneath the stars. Dinner will be served to your suite as the southern sky unfolds.

dayInfo.title: Uluru – Through the Red Desert
dayInfo.description: With a full 24 hours in the desert, you can really appreciate how it changes. This morning, you can walk hand in hand to the greatest rock of them all. Uluru is far bigger than everyone expects, and its beauty surges powerfully from the rough, red earth. A guide will show you Aboriginal stories that are painted into the rock and some of the tales that accompany this spiritual space. Later in the afternoon, you can also travel in the desert, either on horseback, camelback, or quad bikes. Usually, the guides will accompany you on a ride and then leave you to a picnic and bottle of sparkling wine.

dayInfo.title: Uluru – Departure
dayInfo.description: After an optional morning activity, you will begin your journey back home from Uluru’s domestic airport.

tourName: 5 Star New Zealand Luxury Vacation
placesVisited: Cavalli Island, Aotearoa, Rotorua, White Island, Â Wharekauhau Country Estate, Â Abel Tasman National Park, Hawkes Bay, Kahurangi, Queenstown, Central Otago, Fjordland National Park
generalInfo: Superlatives cascade from this vacation of ultimate luxury. Private islands, private yachts, cooking lessons from celebrity chefs, exclusive journeys by helicopter and private jet; and that’s just the start of the opulent indulgence. This prestigious vacation bursts with exacting wonder, New Zealand’s breathtaking natural spectacle unveiled in aristocratic elegance and inimitable style. Raise your expectations and prepare to be amazed.

dayInfo.title: Prestigious Beauty on Your Own Private Island
dayInfo.description: New Zealand’s northern islands dazzle beneath the sun, waves gently lapping against hidden beaches, and sapphire waters dancing into sheltered bays. The faraway waters of Aotearoa are mostly uninhabited, the islands providing a haven for rare wildlife and marine delights. Cavalli Island sits within a protected marine and wildlife sanctuary, home to a secretive private hideaway that redefines stylish island living. You’ll be the only guests; both on the island and in the sanctuary. The enchanting Cavalli Island Retreat and Spa is your base for three days, concealed from the rest of the world and emanating superlatives. A private chef designs a menu to your taste, personal butler and maid attend to every need, and a spa therapist removes any travel aches. Such exclusive elegance is preceded by an exclusive journey, a private jet whisking you away from the airport and cruising into the far north of New Zealand. Ascend above the volcanic leftovers, soaking up lush blue and rolling green before continuing the journey by luxury car and amphibious craft. Settle in and listen. Bird song flickers through the treetops, waves gently loll onto shore, and there’s nothing to break the serenity. This prestigious setting provides the opulent introduction to New Zealand’s wonder.

dayInfo.title: Exploring Your Own Private Marine Sanctuary
dayInfo.description: Your private sanctuary bursts with color and life, the hills filled with native wildlife and a marine world awaiting your eyes. Today is free for you to explore and all the options are included. Perhaps a jet ski or amphibious boat journey, touring past isolated bays and beaches without footprints. Discover a kayak, inflatable lounger, or dinghy; each of them ideal for hanging out the fishing rod. Go snorkeling and admire the untamed aquatics, the sanctuary’s commitment to exclusivity ensuring a world unchanged for millennia. A dive bell with breathing apparatus delves deeper, the macro and the jumbo coming to say hello in the blue. Or take an eight wheel Argo inland, every acre of your private haven ready to be explored. But perhaps today is for indulging in soothing bliss, the Pacific’s best renowned spa therapists creating a unique menu of traditional Maori treatments. Or maybe today is for lounging around in paradise, feasting on the chef’s creations and popping champagne corks. All recreational activities are included so today follows your dream itinerary. After all, it’s your private island.

dayInfo.title: Exclusive Yacht Cruising Through the Islands
dayInfo.description: A whole archipelago awaits as you board the luxuriant Mission Hills , a graceful 72 foot motor yacht that effortlessly travels along the calm waters. An experienced local skipper ensures unparalleled cruising, a pristine myriad of routes providing endless opportunities to indulge. Concealed bays, lost beaches, ancient forests, uninhabited islands; the luscious landscape befits such a regal craft. You’ve got three luxury en suite bedrooms to choose from, indoor and outdoor dining areas, barbecue, indoor and outdoor dining areas, packed entertainment system, kayaks, water skis, snorkeling gear, and an award winning chef tending to your discerning needs. With the sun piercing the horizon, and the water shimmering from blue to green, you find a personal place in paradise to drop anchor. You’ve probably not seen another person all day.

dayInfo.title: Luxurious Chic and Style in the Forest
dayInfo.description: Wave goodbye to your private island and board your private jet, the pilot whisking you onwards to the next exclusive retreat. Ocean waters fade into the distance, replaced by evocative virgin forest and a canopy of native flora. You’re transported into another world and time, nature enveloping your journey with sparkling waterfalls and a green valley of wonder. You’re just outside Rotorua, the heartbeat of Maori culture an omnipresent narrative throughout your stay at the Treetops Lodge and Estate. The ancient tradition of Manaakitanga reigns true here, Maori hosts accepting their responsibility to ensure that visitors always get the best. Ornately carved Rimu doors, wooden beams depicting Maori folklore, lavish rooms filled with local artistic decadence; Treetops Lodge is exclusively made in New Zealand, providing a rich tapestry of luxurious fittings to compliment the jaw-dropping scenery. Each villa is carefully positioned, a stroll or golf buggy ride away from the lodge and imbued with tranquility. Choose from the sumptuous serenity of the virgin forest and a villa framed within nature. Or opt for endless views over lakes and wildlife. Each option comes with fireplace filled lounge, opulent living areas, pre-dinner drinks, and a fabulous four course dinner to delight the palate.

dayInfo.title: Standing on the Edge of a Live Volcanic Crater
dayInfo.description: New Zealand’s North Island is all volcano, the earth rolling with the millennia old deposits of cooled lava and ash. Geothermal activity rumbles beneath the surface and volcanoes continue to mark the landscape. Today you fly by helicopter to White Island and explore an active volcano’s crater. The pilot swoops low, dolphins visible in the ocean below and the iconicity of volcanic peaks stretching across this historic island. Stand on the edge, savoring the inimitability of the country’s most active volcano, gazing down into the inner reaches of this geological wonder. Stop for lunch amongst the rugged charm and then walk on to Mount Tarawera, another dramatic scar on this fault line of fire. After the excitement comes the calm, another night of equanimity at Treetops and another delectable four course dinner.

dayInfo.title: Deep Immersion in Maori Culture and Cuisine
dayInfo.description: When the first European explorers reached New Zealand, a war party of Maori warriors canoed out to meet them. It was spears and handmade weapons against cannons and guns. But the European ships turned around in fear. There’s something unforgettably powerful about the Maori culture; its ancient traditions living on through the centuries and refusing to be diluted by foreign influence. Today you spend a morning with a Maori guide, heading into the forest and harvesting the rich abundance of food and medicine. On this intimate tour you start to explore the misunderstood subtleties of Maori culture, your guide full of answers and evocative explanations. Completing the tour is a Maori style lunch, thick servings of meat and forest delights cooked in the traditional style. The afternoon is free to indulge in the lodge and it’s prodigious exclusivity, with a cozy dinner for two being served in the Lodge Library later in the evening.

dayInfo.title: Indulgent Vineyards and Helicoptering Across New Zealand’s Scenic Wilderness
dayInfo.description: Every aerial of New Zealand bursts with vibrancy and nuance, the landscape framed by a patchwork of expansive forests, remote national parks, charming vineyards, and rugged mountain peaks. This morning you travel by helicopter, crossing the wilderness that Peter Jackson filmed as Middle Earth, and touching down in renowned wine region of Hawkes Bay. A sublime mix of the elusive and the romantic fill your afternoon, the Terroir restaurant bringing a passionate meal of local produce and sommelier selected wines. Roasted chicken sizzles above a roaring wood fire, grilled figs come straight from the tree, and a chic collection of the vineyard’s finest accompany this award-winning luxury lunch. Return to the helicopter and keep shaking your head at the aesthetics, forest and beach guiding the journey to Wharekauhau Country Estate, a 5000 acre farm offering magnificent ocean seclusion. Stand and admire the panorama. The Rimutaka Ranges peer out to the west, the thunderous surf of Palliser Bay stands to the east; surrounding your enchanting cottage above the ocean is a smorgasbord of forest, beach, sheep, river and lakes. Deep sofas, heated marble floors, homemade cookies, gourmet dinners…this is rural New Zealand bliss at its most absolute.

dayInfo.title: An Inimitable Food Day with Celebrity New Zealand Chef, Al Brown
dayInfo.description: Today’s gastronomic journey is guided by celebrity chef,Al Brown; cookbook author, TV presenter, world-famous restaurant owner, and now your personal guide to New Zealand’s finest treats. Al meets you at Wharekauhau as you explore the intricate delights of local cooking. The class starts at the source, a helicopter ride dropping you on a remote section of the Wairarapa Coast where Al’s snorkeling for paua , or native abalone, demonstrating how to shuck this highly prized exotic shellfish. Fly onwards to Greytown for morning tea and contemporary chocolate tasting, then wind into the premium Martinborough vineyards. Two lavish purveyors of sensual rapture fill the next two hours, the vineyards’ narratives revealed over in-depth tasting sessions and a detailed look at the region’s internationally acclaimed pinot noir. Al adds more intoxicating smells to the atmosphere in the second vineyard, offering a hands-on cooking demonstration on how to create his signature paua dish. Sit down and enjoy the delicate nuances of flavor with your celebrity guide, sharing a glass of wine with Al and the local winemaker. A delightful lunch is brought to your table, each individual dish perfectly complimenting this day of unique culinary wonder. You return to Wharekauhau by 4pm, a signed copy of Al’s new book accompanying you in the helicopter.

dayInfo.title: Private Yacht Cruising and Stunning Aerial Journeys Across Kahurangi
dayInfo.description: Today is all about two national parks, each unblemished and awaiting your stylish exploration. Golden beaches and deserted inlets unfurl across Abel Tasman National Park, untamed pieces of paradise inaccessible by land. You arrive by private yacht, a 50 foot cruiser gently traversing the sapphire waters and anchoring in hidden utopia. Swim and sea kayak along the unadulterated blue, relax on concealed beaches, or spend the whole morning sailing through this visual nirvana. After dropping you at the harbor your private helicopter awaits your return, whisking you off after lunch and cruising low through the country’s second largest national park. Kahurangi is raw and rugged, the mountain peaks dominating the northwestern reaches of the South Island. Jagged peaks settle above blankets of greenery, the helicopter soaring along the ridge line and then swooping above elegant lakes and thick forest canopies. Touch down in high alpine wonderment, the helicopter dropping you at Boulder and Mount Benson for unadulterated 360º panoramas of this unique part of the world. Moving from private helicopter to private jet you continue to fly south, coasting over ice-tinged peaks and descending into the pure escapism of Queenstown. You might recognize the vistas around Queenstown; they’ve appeared in hundreds of different movies and commercials. Yet they’re far more authentic from up close. Elegantly perched above Lake Wakatipu, Eichardt’s Private Hotel offers a historical slant to your vacation of unique accommodation. Its gracious strokes and flawless symmetry are the hallmark of New Zealand designer Virginia Fisher, supplemented by the soothing crackle of an open log fire and the untamed opulence of the suites. This is base for the final three nights of your vacation. Catapulting you directly into Queenstown’s chic brilliance is an evening at the Wai Waterfront Restaurant and some unforgettable seafood.

dayInfo.title: A Unique Journey Into World Famous Milford Sound
dayInfo.description: The fjords dance and dazzle across the southern reaches of New Zealand, each expanse of water framed by dramatic ridges of triangular peaks and coatings of snow. Milford Sound is the most famous, the narrow valley rising vertically for over 3000 feet, and the fresh glacial melt mixing with salty ocean water. But it’s just one of many sounds and fjords you’ll see today, a breathtaking helicopter ride unveiling Fjordland National Park in all its primitive natural glory. It’s a journey of contrasts, the white wonderland juxtaposed with warm West Coast beaches and lush sites to uncork the champagne and take a picnic. Just like every aerial voyage on this vacation, there’s a wonderfully unhurried pace today. Take your time, soak up nature’s marvels and then return to Queenstown and an elegant evening of dining at the Saffron Restaurant in Arrowtown. With the aesthetic delights of Fjordland fresh in the memory, a vintage bottle of red is the idyllic accompaniment to a dinner of the freshest South Island ingredients.

dayInfo.title: A Boutique Vineyard Tour Through Central Otago
dayInfo.description: After a tranquil morning at leisure, probably lingering over breakfast in the hotel’s lavish parlor, you spend the day combining spectacular scenery with boutique vineyard heaven. Wind along deserted mountain roads, passing numerous sights from Peter Jackson’s Middle Earth and stopping to taste the enchanting creations at four to five different wineries. Panoramas accompany the subtle whites and a mesmeric platter lunch goes with rich reds, before historic Old Cromwell Town adds more doses of charm to the menu. Like always, expect a leisurely pace and tailoring the journey to your own tastes and preferences. Completing your insatiable itinerary of gastronomic treats, tonight’s evening meal is at Gantleys, one of New Zealand’s oldest and most celebrated restaurants. The exterior screams history, an 1863 building surrounded by Queenstown’s majestic mountain backdrop. Then the interior comes alive with flickering smells and cozy ambience, dinner for two served in the intimate and exclusive wine library. A carefully blended degustation menu takes your senses on a delicate journey, the food and wine pairings are tantalizing yet powerful.

dayInfo.title: A Final Private Jet Ride Before Your International Departure
dayInfo.description: After an unhurried morning your private jet takes off one final time, whisking you across the South Island to Christchurch and your international departure. Keep savoring the views as the pilot swoops low over this nation of superlatives, before meeting your scheduled international connection and returning home with a lifetime of memories. Each facet of this remarkable luxury journey is fully customizable to your individual preferences. For traveler reviews, visit the section on New Zealand travel agents .

tourName: A Scenic North and South Island New Zealand Discovery
placesVisited: Auckland, Whitianga, Rotorua, Napier, Masterson, Wellington, Picton, Kaikoura, Christchurch, Mount Cook, Queenstown, Franz Josef Township
generalInfo: Capture immense scenic beauty comprising diverse landscapes and cultural wonders on this 17-Day Scenic North and South Island New Zealand Discovery tour. Spend time in Auckland, Wellington, and Christchurch; embrace lush forests; explore pristine beaches; and wander sharp-tipped mountains as you self-drive through the dramatic landscape. Experience majestic Milford Sound and ride the skyline gondola in Queenstown as you discover the grandeur of New Zealand at your pace.

dayInfo.title: Auckland - Unveil the Diverse Landscape of Auckland
dayInfo.description: Start your scenic New Zealand adventure in the captivating city of Auckland, with its diverse and breathtaking cityscapes. Chilled open spaces meet towering buildings, beaches and forests compliment each other as contrasting playgrounds of sand and soil, while the cosmopolitan vibe of urban dwelling teeters on the edge of adventure in a city where work meets play in a picturesque setting. Embrace rich art culture with a walk through the Toi o Tamaki Art Gallery, a display of classic and contemporary photographs, or wander through Aotea Square, which buzzes day and night with sounds of music and murmurs from locals and visitors.

dayInfo.title: Auckland - Explore the ‘City of Sails’
dayInfo.description: On a small stretch of land between the Tasmanian Sea and the Hauraki Gulf, Auckland is the site of tall masts and neatly tied sails, as perfectly parked boats dot the shimmering waters surrounding the city. Take time today to explore this island of wonder, perhaps walking pedestrian-only Vulcan Lane, the aroma of rich arabica beans filling the air, the sound of a busker strumming soulful tunes as you pass cafes and boutiques. Explore the Devonport neighborhood, where the variety of quaint breakfast cafes, upmarket pubs, and deli-style restaurants lining the harbor promenade leave visitors spoiled for choice. Step inside the Peter Raos Studio, intricate glass art offering brilliant design and color.

dayInfo.title: Whitianga - Travel along a Coastline of Coves and Caves
dayInfo.description: Your car will be delivered to you today, in time for you to set out for the east coast, passing the lush plains of Hauraki and keeping an eye out for the brilliant flash of birdlife off the shores of Miranda. Arriving in the coastal gem of Whitianga, you can take a boat ride to the edge of paradise and explore the wonders of Cathedral Cove, the diverse hues of red blossoms from the Pohutukawa Tree a vibrant contrast to surrounding greens and browns. Inhale fresh coastal air as you stop to admire Cathedral Cove. This massive lime formation looms out from a carpet of golden sand, an impressive display of nature’s architecture.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua - Discover the Scenic Bay of Plenty
dayInfo.description: Leave the Coromandel Peninsula in your rearview mirror as you travel south to the picturesque Bay of Plenty. True to its name, this is one of New Zealand’s most-loved playgrounds, a natural wonder of sand, sea, and sun-kissed locations offering myriad activities and a chance to simply unwind. You may wish to indulge in a feast of local fare and flare with Maori-inspired hangi , earthy flavors of chicken cooked underground for several hours, resulting in a juicy, smokey dish. Enjoy the tradition of the kapa haka , the “war cry” of a bold Maori ceremony demonstrating pride and community that’s meant to instill fear in adversaries through bold, bellowing gestures and sounds. The ground can feel like it’s shuddering with every motion and utterance.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua - Experience Maori Tradition and Geothermal Landmarks
dayInfo.description: Discover the active volcanic region of Rotorua, bubbling hot springs and smoking geysers covering the landscape of this mineral-rich destination, where the land’s robust rumbles are met with thundering dances and traditions of the Maori tribe. Take the opportunity to walk under a thick canopy of forest ferns that leads to a sacred space of circular sand patterns and humble thatch and wooden homes, and listen to stories of how Tane, Lord of the Forest, separated earth and sky. Take a turn at the Wai-O-Tapu Thermal Wonderland and gaze in awe at the seemingly unreal rusty-red earth dusting an arid gray and green landscape, mud pools and hot springs painting a misty picture of rugged, geometric texture.

dayInfo.title: Napier - Visit Captivating Waterfalls and Panoramic Vineyards
dayInfo.description: Your adventure takes you to the shores of New Zealand’s largest freshwater lake, Lake Taupo. Glints of silver bounce off the shimmering blue and turquoise waters, while the frenzy of foaming white water cascades over Huka Falls. You may wish to jet boat your way through the rapid waters, the cool spray of mist against your skin, the whooshing sound of waves heightened by the thrill of it all. As twilight falls, your sundowner wine experience beckons. Admire captivating views of swirling green mountain slopes and valleys from the top of Te Mata Peak while sipping a glass of pinot noir. The volcanic soil in the region presents wines with cherry and raspberry flavors that are prominent with each sip.

dayInfo.title: Wellington - Drive By Rolling Hills, Wineries, and Wildlife
dayInfo.description: Discover the fertile land that runs through the Manawatu region, contrasted by sheer slopes and the cliffs of Manawatu Gorge. Sheep add a splash of white to the green and gold fields and farms, while neat rows of vineyards break the landscape, adding another delightful element to a day out in southeastern North Island. You may wish to consider an evening adventure, during which you can embrace cute and charming animals at a wildlife sanctuary that’s a refuge for rare, native wildlife. Keep an eye out for the spikey tuatara, New Zealand's prehistoric-looking lizard, and the beloved kiwi, its browny-gray ruffled feathers resembling a hedgehog, its slender toothpick-like beak ready to snatch some food at any time.

dayInfo.title: Wellington - Explore New Zealand’s Culinary Capital
dayInfo.description: A capital city that offers cosmopolitan charm and a menu of culinary locales that include quirky eateries set down eerie alleyways, among them Alice, its gaudy oval mirrors, hanging lanterns, and red-themed dining areas paying homage to the Queen of Hearts. Indulge in a colorful collage of fruit and vegetables displayed at the Riverbank food market, the smell of fresh bread filling the air as you walk by pop-up bakeries. Try your hand at shucking fresh, meaty New Zealand oysters under the guidance of a culinary professional during a cooking class. Later, take a turn on the Wellington Cable Car ride to the top of Kelburn Hill, the jagged cityscape and Te Whanganui-a-Tara harbor shrinking before your eyes.

dayInfo.title: Kaikoura - Enjoy a Picturesque Ferry Ride to South Island
dayInfo.description: Leave your car, but bring along your memories of New Zealand’s North Island as you take a ferry to its southern counterpart. The natural beauty of grassy mounds and sharp rocks jutting out of the water is complemented by the Pencarrow Head Lighthouse, its stark, white-washed exterior standing out in brilliance against nature’s browns and greens. Notice rocks swaying in the ocean and discover they are in fact seals dancing on Red Rock. Admire the dramatic Kaikoura Ranges as you cruise around Marlborough Sounds, a collection of valleys drenched by rising seas, with a chance to capture key features, such as secluded bays and sunlight dancing off glistening waters. Back on land, collect your car and wind your way to Kaikoura village.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - Experience Whale Watching and Waipara Valley
dayInfo.description: Set out early onto the wavy waters around Kaikoura for the chance of a close encounter of the gentle kind. Giant sperm whales glide under and over the dancing waters amid marine life comprising orcas, fur seals, and tiny Hector’s dolphins. Your catamaran sways to and fro above a fascinating and dramatic submarine landscape, the continental shelf’s sudden drop fading into myriad underwater canyons. Take a turn inland through the Waipara Valley, a wine region kissed with warm north-westerly winds, vines creeping up the Teviotdale Hills. Before reaching Christchurch for the evening, you can stop and sip a crisp riesling, the nectarine and pear flavors offering a smooth finish and a honeycomb aroma.

dayInfo.title: Mount Cook - Step Into a Natural Masterpiece
dayInfo.description: Driving through the center of South Island, the contrasting terrain of the Canterbury Plains, winding Burke’s Pass, and the lakeside town of Tekapo with its chilling turquoise waters, will make you feel as if you have climbed inside a vibrant mural. Take in the sight of the country’s tallest mountain, Mt Cook, and jump at the chance for an aerial view of the Mt Cook National Park, the snaking wooden walkways set through the park looking like splinters in the hand of nature. Visit the Church of the Good Shepherd, the simple yet sturdy stone structure surrounded by grass, rocks, and open spaces. As you wander through and around this iconic New Zealand landmark, tranquil energy may come over you.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - Drive Mountain Passes, Sheer Cliffs, and Bridges
dayInfo.description: Start your journey at lake level, driving through picturesque Twizel, the ideal base from which to explore mountains and hiking trails, do a spot of fishing, or simply watch a breathtaking orange and pink sunset from nearby Lake Ruataniwha. Stop by the small farming village of Terras and catch a glimpse of the fascinating natural wonder of pink and white terraced earth striations that resemble a cloud that fell from the sky. Notice how the layers seem to flow into crystal waters and disappear. The natural drama continues as you squeeze through the sheer cliffs of the Kawarau Gorge and gaze upon distant vineyards, wineries, and mountains guiding you toward Queenstown.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - Uncover a City of Gastronomy and Natural Wonder
dayInfo.description: Queenstown is a go-to destination for any outdoor enthusiast, wedged between Lake Wakatipu and the sharp and sheer Remarkable Mountain Range. Stretch your legs and your fitness level as you hike the winding Ben Lomond Trail, which offers a 360-degree view over jagged mountain ranges and sneaky pockets of water. After a day of action, you may wish to satisfy your hunger with a unique dining experience aboard a 100-year-old steamship, the menu comprising a hearty barbeque of local meats served with salads and mouth-watering desserts, among them creamy chocolate tarts and citrus-flavored gelato. Later, ride the Skyline Gondola for captivating nighttime views.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - Cruise and Walk Magical Milford Sound
dayInfo.description: Sit back and relax today as someone else takes the wheel and guides you along the shores of Lake Wakatipu and over the rolling landscape, weaving through breathtaking scenery. Enjoy a beverage break in Te Anau, its name apt for the swirling waters surrounding your focus destination today. Reaching Milford Sound, cruise the mirror-like surface of the breathtaking fjord, the mountains reflected in the crystal waters seemingly even larger than they really are. Peaks flow into valleys and shorelines disappear below cascading waterfalls. Hear the rush of water as you slowly pass by, rainforests adding a tropical atmosphere to this surreal sight. Look out for the rare blue duck or black and white splashes of Fiordland penguins at play.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef Township - Enjoy Forest Walks and Rugged Coastlines
dayInfo.description: Reaching for new heights, drive across New Zealand’s Crown Range, the country’s most elevated main road, with options to stop in villages and towns nestled among picturesque lake and mountain backdrops, among them Wanaka, a true wonderland in winter. The waters of Lake Wanaka offer a refreshing splash against the mountainsides and towering trees. Witness the magic of ice valleys that flow from snowlines to the sea when you walk the iced-walled trails of Franz Josef Glacier, noticing cracks and crevices created from years of glacial retreat. Take in magnificent views of nearby Fox Glacier, the frosty blue and white gleaming in the distance.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - Take a Scenic Train Ride from West to East
dayInfo.description: Your last day of adventure has you passing through the gold mining region of Hokitika, the town of the same name small in area, yet large and rich in history. Capture stories of the gold rush displayed in museums and along heritage trails, tales of ships that ran aground on the “Hokitika Bar” and the perseverance of many as they fought for the chance to strike it rich. Leave your vehicle in Greymouth and board the TranzAlpine Scenic Train to travel from west to east through beech forest, past the breathtaking peaks of the Southern Alps, and along lush river valleys. Feast your eyes on the golds and browns of the familiar Canterbury plains before reaching Christchurch.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - A Classic End to an Inspirational Adventure
dayInfo.description: Take some time to walk through Christchurch before your transfer to the airport in time for your flight out. Perhaps visit the 195 chairs monument, a haunting site of chairs of varying designs simply set on grass to represent the lives lost in the 2011 earthquake. Maybe there will be time to wander around Christchurch Square, listening to buskers and people-watching as locals rush about their day.

tourName: Adventures of New Zealand's South Island
placesVisited: Christchurch, Mount Cook, Queenstown, Franz Josef, Greymouth
generalInfo: Soar to New Zealand for nine days of essential exploration through its Southern Alpines. This tour showcases the frosted allure of New Zealand's picturesque landscapes. Beginning in the buzzing city of Christchurch and culminating atop the icy summit of Franz Josef, every second of this tour will bring you closer to the surreal spectacles that sweep New Zealand’s Southern summits.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - An Evergreen Countryside
dayInfo.description: Devastatingly affected by a natural disaster some years ago, Christchurch has since rebuilt and reconstructed into a vibrant New Zealand cityscape. Luxuriant gardens and flowering trees line buzzing boulevards, and decorated cathedrals offset the gentrification of the city. After transferring to your comfy accommodation surrounded by the evergreen, you will be immersed in the colorful character of the city. With an evening to unwind, you may visit a local artisanal restaurant for a taste of New Zealand’s multicultural delights with a backdrop of the bucolic countryside.

dayInfo.title: Mount Cook - Snow-Capped Peaks
dayInfo.description: You will collect your rental car early this morning and set off across New Zealand’s Southern countryside toward the Mount Cook. En route, you will cross the mesmerizing Canterbury plains and pass through lakeside towns until images of Mount Cook’s snow-capped summit peeks from between the emerald valleys. Within this mountain landscape, you may explore the picturesque icy glaciers that are often overshadowed by frozen cliffs and rising icebergs. The vistas will be sweeping and endless whichever way you look.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - Over the Southern Alps
dayInfo.description: You will travel away from the Alpine region today toward the mountains of Queenstown. Set against the Southern Alps, the lakeside town’s locale is a marvel to behold. Its allure is reinforced by the charming character that emanates through its friendly neighborhoods. You will then discover the appeal of Queenstown shortly after arriving during a delightful cruise across the calm lake. As the mist hangs low against the mountains and the sunset burns across the sky, you will tuck into delicacies served on deck and sip on tasteful wine.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - The Doubtful Sound
dayInfo.description: The momentous Lake Wakatipu is fringed by towering olive-green hills of thick forests. On a coach and boat tour of the lake, these enchanting scenes will be clearer than ever, allowing you to bask in the scenic beauty that prevails across Southern New Zealand. After accessing the phenomenal Doubtful Sound fjord from the lake, you will lose yourself in the pleasures of this pure and unspoiled environment. The landscape boasts shimmering rainforests with plant life and gushing waterfalls, making every moment will be worth capturing.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown - The Finer Side of Life
dayInfo.description: While adventure abounds across the luxuriant landscape that surrounds Queenstown, the destination is also the ideal place to rest and enjoy the idyllic countryside. You may spend your day delighting in the endearing cultural heritage highlights of Queenstown at your own pace, starting along the Gibbston Valley wine trail for tastes of the region’s premier Pinot. After indulging yourself, you may glide across the lake by gondola for views of the unparalleled scenery.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef - Thermal Glacier Pools
dayInfo.description: Today, you will venture from Queenstown across the highest sealed road in New Zealand, the Crown Range, to the charming town of Wanaka. Surrounded by remote settlements and glacier pools, Wanaka is a postcard-perfect destination. Your travels will continue after appreciating the astonishing scenery, bringing you to the vitalizing thermal glacier pools of Franz Josef. Enveloped by the towering green trees and sounds of chirping birds, you will dip into the balmy pools. There are few places on Earth as peaceful and beautiful as these natural glacier baths within the rainforest.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef - On the Frosty Crest
dayInfo.description: Franz Josef is an admirable town stationed in one of New Zealand’s most remarkable destinations. Its mountains are drenched in thick rainforest, and its peaks are coated in layers of ice. Atop these crests, you will enjoy an unforgettable glacier hike, weaving in and out of wondrous ice formations to viewpoints that overlook the endless countryside. The frosty formations yearn to be captured in images and memories that will last a lifetime, and serenity can be found in the tranquility of the unspoiled landscape rarely touched by the human hand.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - Spectacular Scenes
dayInfo.description: Your journey will bring you back to Christchurch in the most fantastic way: on a breathtaking train trip through the countryside between Greymouth and Christchurch. Argued to be the most scenic train trip on Earth, this ride will meet you with incredible views of the untamed wilderness and soaring peaks of the Southern Alps. The forests will glow under the sun, and the deep river valleys will trickle between stark gorges. Eventually, you will arrive and Christchurch, where a driver will transfer you to your accommodation.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch - Departure
dayInfo.description: Your Southern New Zealand experiences will sadly come to an end today; however, you will have the morning in Christchurch to cherish before transferring to the airport. You may casually bask in the stunning scenery from a quiet bench in the landscaped parks, tuck into delightful dishes, or appreciate the stained-glass murals of the city's finest churches. Regardless, you will leave no stone unturned during your final moments in New Zealand.

tourName: Adventurous Two-Week South Island Family Vacation
placesVisited: Queenstown, Â Blenheim, Â Christchurch, Doubtful Sound
generalInfo: Your epic two-week family-friendly New Zealand tour will create unforgettable memories of timeless adventures on the South Island. You can swim with dolphins and cycle down winding hilltop trails. Kayaking on clear turquoise waters will provide surprising wildlife sightings. Cruise through the pristine wilderness of Doubtful Sound and immerse the family in Middle Earth by visiting Lord of the Rings filming locations for a dynamic New Zealand family excursion.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Relaxing Along the Lakeshore
dayInfo.description: Queenstown is a small and relaxed town that is located beneath the mountains and along the lakeshore. The scenery is majestic, and it is quick to inspire with slithers of snow reflecting in the soft blue waters of Lake Wakatipu. A small-town harbor will have restaurants and a European-style square, while the main town will be a block of four horizontal and vertical streets. Your hotel is located just off the water and will be your base for the next week. You will check-in after the airport transfer and get your bearings in Queenstown.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Family Adventure Along the River
dayInfo.description: Today you will be zooming in on a family river trip down the Shotover River. While this may sound intense for young children, this adventure activity is extremely safe and was even visited by Queen Elizabeth II not too long ago. Rushing down Shotover River will certainly get your family's blood flowing, and it is a good introduction for showing the kids all the fun that can be had in New Zealand as the wind and the mist splash against your cheeks. Onsen hot pools are nearby, providing a much needed hour of rest after the river ride.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Lord of the Rings Filming Locations Tour
dayInfo.description: Standing in Gladden Fields, you will relive the loss of the ring. In Kawarau Gorge, you will look upon Argonath, which is the location of the Valley of the Kings in the movie. Gazing down from a hilly summit, you can see Rohan and the place where the Ambush of the Wargs was filmed. Your guide will tell stories of Queenstown locals appearing as extras as you find more Lord of the Rings filming locations. This private adventure will culminate in your family donning cloaks and swords as you pose for photos that could have come straight from The Hobbit.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Exploring the Mountains
dayInfo.description: Today, you will rise above Queenstown by gondola and gaze out across the lake. The Remarkables mountains create a panorama, and the lakes will reflect the mirrored image. Up here, you can try a form of family karting. Many kids will complete their allotted five laps and want to keep going forever. Many easy hiking trails head off from here. If you are the adventurous type, you can zipline and walk back into town, choose some of New Zealand’s best downhill mountain biking, or try your hand at hang gliding.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – A 3-D Maze and a Puzzling World in Wanaka
dayInfo.description: Today, you will enter the world’s first 3-D maze. It is all deliberately weird and wonderful, such as impossible stairs, puzzling toilets, odd proportions, and holograms. The main attraction is a maze that unfolds on many levels. After Puzzling World, you will be taken to a quiet world, where you can relax in the stunning scenery around Mount Aspiring National Park. The alpine lakes and Red Hills offer an astonishing diversity shaped by the active tectonic plates over millennia. You can trek to the Blue Pools to find glacier-fed waters or enjoy the views over Lake Wanaka.

dayInfo.title: Doubtful Sound – An Expedition onto the Fjords
dayInfo.description: You will leave Queenstown for the day on an expedition across the water in a small boat, feeling modern civilization slipping into the background. You will disembark and cross a headland, bumping up to Wilmot Pass. Soon you will be enveloped by the fjord. Waterfalls will gush out from stark rock, and cliffs will rise to seemingly endless heights at Doubtful Sound, an impressive fiord. You can kayak in the fiord or ride along the coast in a small boat for a lovely feeling of tranquility after the day’s escapades.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Returning After the Overnight Cruise
dayInfo.description: Today, you will wake up with nature all around. The cliffs are majestic as they soar to nearly half a mile above you. The boat will look small in such surroundings, and even the dolphins and waterfalls will appear in miniature. This morning will be a lot like yesterday afternoon, with a mix of cruising around the fjord and your choice of a kayak or small boat excursion. After lunch, you will disembark and make the beautiful return journey to civilization. This evening will likely be quiet and serene.

dayInfo.title: Blenheim – A Little of Wine Country After the Adventure
dayInfo.description: You will have an early flight north to Blenheim, where you will swap New Zealand’s adventure capital with its most famous wine region. You will be staying in Blenheim, and you will quickly discover more than just wine. Trails run off in all directions, providing an excellent opportunity for walking and cycling. The coast is only ten minutes away, and the town has a grand selection of shops and cafés. After a week spent focused on activities for the kids, settle into an exploration of the vineyards with a moment of tranquility.

dayInfo.title: Blenheim – Seals and Seabirds in Marlborough Sounds
dayInfo.description: Today, you will be going on a half-day cruise through the Marlborough Sounds. Various dolphin and seal species can be seen here, with fins rising above the surface as seabirds dive dramatically into the water. Sometimes the birds will emerge with silver slivers of fish, and other times they will seem to come up exhausted, barely able to shake the water from their wings. After lunch on the boat, the afternoon will be free, and the area is superb for hiking. All of these will offer breathtaking views of the sounds for all of you to enjoy.

dayInfo.title: Blenheim – Cycling and Kayaking for All Ages
dayInfo.description: Today will be left free, and there will be several activities that can bring your family together. New Zealand is for all ages, and there is a stunning network of trails, so you can easily find a cycle or walking route that suits you and your family. Marlborough is rural, and as you cycle around, you can stop at vineyards or enjoy the view. You could also take an adventurous trip to Abel Tasman National Park to find small coves and empty tropical beaches. Out there, you may discover Manta rays and turtles visible from a kayak.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Learning About Earthquakes and Change
dayInfo.description: You will fly to Christchurch, where you will have an educational day exploring the charm of the Garden City. Much of the city was rebuilt after the 2011 earthquake, and quintessential beauty stems from the architecture to blossoming flowers. As you walk the streets with your local guide, you will see how well the city uses art and innovative design to craft a unique aesthetic from Lyttleton Harbour to the city center. Christchurch has become a symbol of nature’s power and humanity’s determination to grow. After a relaxed, half-day tour, the evening will be at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Swimming with the World’s Smallest Dolphins
dayInfo.description: Most people think of dolphins as big things, however, Hector’s Dolphins are more childlike in size. They are the world’s rarest and smallest oceanic dolphins, and you can swim with them at Akaroa. Soon you will be jumping into the water, and some may even leap before your eyes. Through the mask, you can watch how they corkscrew to ridiculous depths before rising back to the surface. Perhaps, the most impressive aspect of the dolphins are the sounds they make. With your head in the water, you can hear all the communicative tweets.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – A Family Antarctic Experience (Without Getting Too Cold)
dayInfo.description: This final day will mostly be left free. So, pack up your things, do some souvenir shopping, and reflect on the journey that has been before it is time to head home. You might choose to explore Antarctica at the interpretation center. Inside the award-winning center, you will explore simulation rooms, seeing what it is actually like to be at the South Pole. For a brief moment, it will be windy and freezing cold. You can also spot penguins waddling along the landscape. The simulation rooms also explain the challenges, human history, wildlife, and expeditions of Antarctica.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Departure
dayInfo.description: After breakfast your family will be transferred to the international airport for your outbound flight home bringing an end to your fabulous New Zealand adventure as a family.

tourName: Amazing Family Friendly Tour of New Zealand: Queenstown, Rotorua, Pauanui, Tairua, and More
placesVisited: Christchurch, Akaroa, Mount Cook Village, Queenstown, Rotorua
generalInfo: The Remarkables Mountains frame the South Island and reflect in the pristine waters of glacial lakes. Turquoise waves lap at gold sand beaches. Forests decorate the hills and valleys. You can hear the cultural songs of the Maori echoing from a long tradition. Your amazing family friendly tour of New Zealand through Queenstown, Rotorua, Pauanui, Tairua and more is tailored to provide family adventure and cultural discoveries. View the smoldering crater lake of a volcanic island and watch penguins dive into the frigid waters of a breathtaking fiord. The family will find exploration of land, air, and sea along the treasured landscape and heritage of New Zealand.

dayInfo.title: Garden Arrival
dayInfo.description: Christchurch is a city of rich cultural gardens that touch on the English heritage of New Zealand’s colonial past. The Avon River winds gently through the city, from Hagley Park to the cobble-paved streets of the city center. Botanic Gardens offer colorful blossoming flowers to antique stone buildings and art projects that have sprouted since the aftermath of the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes. Local are friendly and greet every new face with a wide smile. They embrace the innovation of the refurbished city and the excited visitors that come from around the world. The family arrives and your private transfer meets you at the airport. The city maintains a small town charm that makes you feel as though you have stepped into an English village instead of one of the largest cities in New Zealand. Magnificent snowcapped mountains dwarf the skyline and encompass the cityscape. The family marvels at the quaint character of the city and the stunning landscape that surrounds it.

dayInfo.title: Pristine Panoramas
dayInfo.description: The family wakes up to the offerings of a traditional breakfast. The hardy meal readies you for the active day to come. Your private transfer meets you at the airport and escorts the family to the charming town of Akaroa. The historic French settlement maintains its fishing village allure. Colonial architecture lines the streets around the city center and climb into the shallow foothills. Cafes emanate the aromas of fresh brioche and rich coffee. The kids don’t try to hide the fact that even they have been delighted by the ambiance of the city. Stop aboard a harbor cruise and venture out onto the cobalt blue water. The sea air surrounds you and the boat sprays cool water into the air. Dramatic cliffs and verdant foothills encompass the harbor. Sea caves are carved into the landscape. Hector’s Dolphins burst from the water and the family gasps with excitement. They can grow over five feet long and have a unique dorsal fin that’s rounded at the top. Put on a wetsuit and spend time in the water visiting with the dolphins. The water is briny and refreshingly cold. The coastline sits in the distance. Dolphins swim near you. They look straight at you and bob their heads with excitement. Although the dolphins look like they’re smiling at you, when you look back at your family you can see their radiant smiles.

dayInfo.title: Whitewashed Landscape
dayInfo.description: At the center of New Zealand’s illustrious South Island is the Aoraki Mount Cook Mackenzie region. At night, the stars flicker brilliantly in the unobstructed sky. During the day, the sunlight drapes over the mountains and valleys with enthusiastic light, spotlighting the turquoise lakes, emerald grass, and snowcapped mountain peaks. The family ventures out on an excursion that takes them along celebrated glaciers. Step aboard a boat and course along the Tasman Glacier terminal lake. The water is stiffly cold, and you journey close enough to touch, and even taste, 300-500 year-old glacial crystals. In the calm journey across the water, your guide quiets everyone. If you listen closely, you can hear the ice breaking away from the rest of the glacier to form icebergs of all shapes and sizes. You travel along the lake surrounded by the breathtaking alpine scenery. The natural beauty of the mountains and the raw power of the glaciers captivate the family.

dayInfo.title: Endless Sounds
dayInfo.description: The kids’ enthusiasm hasn’t waned, and they wake up eagerly awaiting the next adventure. After breakfast, your transfer meets you at the hotel and takes you south to the edges of Fiordland National Park, home to the famous Milford Sound. The first impression is breathtaking. Rocky cliffs rise out of pristine, dark water. Forests sprout from craggy foothills and drape steep slopes. Mitre Peak stands 5,551 feet above sea level and often displays a snowy top. The family boards the boat and cruises the remarkable scenery across the Sound. The large cruise ship takes you between watery mountain passes and alongside the far-reaching sloping edges. Stirling Falls is a permanent waterfall that cascades 508 feet down the cliffside into the waiting sea below. The water trundles past mossy rocks and stirs the air. Little Blue Penguins can grow up to 17 inches in height and have a particular blue sheen that matches the color of the dark water. Colonies waddle on the forested beachside and dive into the water in search of fish. You point the penguins out to the kids and the watch with bemusement as this unforgettable contact with nature shapes into a personal memory.

dayInfo.title: Speeding Up River
dayInfo.description: A skyline shaped by the Remarkables Mountains surrounds Queenstown. Their peaks reflect in the opulent waters of Lake Wakatipu. The alpine village is known for as the extreme capital of New Zealand but also maintains a small town atmosphere with an energetic ambiance. Your guide meets you at your hotel and takes the family to the edges of the Dart River for an exciting excursion on the water and adjacent landscape. When you board the boat you aren’t sure what to expect but soon the kids cry out with excitement as the boat speeds up river providing a unique view of the scenery and mythological Maori history. Freshwater sprays around the boat. The breeze brushes through your hair and the scent of limestone and beech wood fill the air. The landscape resembles an imaginative Middle Earth and was used in several scenes of the Lord of the Rings Trilogy. The forests have remained the same for around 80 million years. Turquoise blue water edges lush riverbanks. The forests fade to pebble shores before the trees return. Towering, snowy mountains encase the river. When the snow melts waterfalls feed into the Dart River.

dayInfo.title: Legends of the People
dayInfo.description: Rotorua is the cultural capital of New Zealand. The city is known for its dynamic thermal springs and spouting geysers, but also a home to the Maori’s Sacred Waters. Your private transfer takes you the airport for your flight to the city filled with legends. The thermal reserve of Te Puia is home to more than 500 springs, including Pohutu, also known as “Big Splash,” which erupts up to 20 times a day. The water spouts almost 100 feet upwards. In the evening, you will visit a Maori village for a sample of the heritage and continued cultural connection with the indigenous peoples of the island. The aromas of slow cooking lamb and vegetables emanate from the hungi, an earthen oven dug into the ground. The local tribe performs a welcome ceremony and introduces the traditions of its people upon welcoming guests. After dinner, it offers you a look at the famous haka , the war dance. The celebrated All Blacks,rugby team performs the dance before every game to intimidate their rivals. A drum beats and the warriors slap their chests and thighs to the rhythm. They bulge their eyes and stick out their tongues. The effect is captivating and chilling. The beat quickens and the warriors stomp their feet and continue to slap their chest. The family is fascinated with the dance and the battle cry that echoes deep into the night.

dayInfo.title: Visions of the Simmering Land
dayInfo.description: A mist drifts off of Lake Rotorua in the morning light that comes from the subterranean heat of the region. It offers a unique and interesting view of the city and the landscape. In the morning, you step away from the city of hot springs for an aerial view of crater lakes and Mount Tarawera, along with White Island, home to the country’s most active offshore volcano. Over 30 miles from the mainland’s shores is the simmering conical peak of White Island. You can see vapor rising from the summit. From the sky, the island looks like a photographed image of a perfect volcanic landmass out of a movie. Smoke rises from the crater’s acrid lake at the island’s center. The family sees power and beauty in the same moment, in one panorama of White Island, set in the enveloping deep blue waters of the Bay of Plenty.

dayInfo.title: Twin Harbors
dayInfo.description: Today you leave behind the images of volcanoes and geysers, Maoris, and the haka. Tairua and Pauanui are twin towns divided by an estuary on the North Island’s east coast. The hillside of Paku has twin cones and a sculpted hillside. You can see the shores of the Alderman Islands from the beach. The water is a perfect cool temperature. The green edges of the cities pull back from the ocean and drape the rolling mountains that cover the horizon. The day is at your leisure to indulge in the scenery and perhaps relax on the on the beach. You find Tairua beach at the edge of Mount Paku’s foothills. The sun shines bright and warm over the sand and the water shimmers opulent blue. The sand is gold and soft. You can hear the water splash against the distant rocks at the edge of the estuary. The family takes the day to rejuvenate in the on the stunning beachside with the sweet breeze blowing passed.

dayInfo.title: A Cove and Cathedral
dayInfo.description: The clear turquoise water of New Zealand’s northeast coast continues to enthrall the family. The thermal springs of Hahei Beach filter into the ocean and heat the Pacific to a temperate cool. The town is quaint and sits against the opulent water. Caves are hidden by the sloping trees and hide quiet, secret beaches. Venture out on a kayak tour of Cathedral Cove and experience the marine reserve up close and personal. The family is excited about the next adventure. Follow your guide along limestone rock formations that rise out of the water. Whales swim in the distance. The sand looks soft and inviting. You pass beside karsts and underneath stone arches shaped by the elements. Spend time enjoying the sights from a sea cave. Water laps at the shore and echoes against the stone cavern.

dayInfo.title: Wonders of the Water
dayInfo.description: Auckland is the largest city in New Zealand is knows as the “City of Sails.” Marinas grace the shoreline and numerous boats sway in the soft wake. On any given day, you can look out on the water and see boats casting their sails and catching the breeze. They glide across the sea like passing clouds. The city boasts the largest Polynesian population outside of the islands and emanates a friendly, eclectic atmosphere. The Sky Tower stands 1,076 feet tall and with a 360-degree view of the city. Make your way to the interactive aquarium at Kelly Tarlton’s for a view of subaquatic and arctic life. The habitat was opened in 1985 and continues to provide over 360 feet of tunnels to view passing fish and sharks. Stroll alongside the arctic encounter to view penguins up close in a simulated glacial environment. Stand at the edge of a 92,000-gallon tank and see stingray gliding through the water. You can watch staff enter the tank and feed the large and unique looking animal, pointing out the eyes atop their body and their mouths underneath. Even in the cities the natural splendor of New Zealand is present and prevalent.

dayInfo.title: Returning from the Waterfront
