It will be wild and remote and is an area unseen and inaccessible without a boat tour. As you disembark, you will take tentative steps onto the country’s largest glacier.

dayInfo.title: Dunedin – Quaint Scottish Heritage
dayInfo.description: Nestled between mountain and lake, Omarama basks in its scenic location. Draped along the coast, Oamaru delights in its explorer’s heritage. There is also scenic splendor here, particularly at Koekohe Beach and the Moeraki Boulders. Like most of the road journeys on this tour, you will not travel directly to the next overnight destination. Short stops in Omarama and Oamaru will help you see everything the island has to offer, as well as keeping the journeys manageable and engaging. As this is a private tour, there will be flexibility as well, so you choose how long to stay in each place, make fewer or more stops, and also adjust the timings dependent on your mood.

dayInfo.title: Dunedin – Up Close with Penguins and Other Rare Wildlife
dayInfo.description: Dunedin’s railway station will appear like a gingerbread house and is just one piece of the Scottish heritage that sweeps through this windswept, coastal town. Cafés and pubs will seem more Edinburgh than New Zealand, while the wild beaches and unpredictable weather will provide further similarities. It is a lovely little town to explore on a half-day tour, passing through eclectic architecture to Dunedin Harbour. From here, you will set sail as you cruise to the breeding place of yellow-eyed penguins. Sounds will be cacophonous in nearby wetlands, where birds wade and flutter colorful wings. Seabirds will dive like arrows into harbor waters, occasionally coming back up with a silverfish. When dusk arrives and the temperature sinks, there will be a Scottish style pub where you can warm up beside an open fire.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Taieri Gorge Train to the Shores of Lake Wakatipu
dayInfo.description: Departing from the gingerbread house, a train will take you West across magnificent single-track bridges and railway sections that have been carved out from raw mountain rock. Taieri Gorge was an immense engineering feat, and you can forgive the train’s slow pace, for it is not easy to carve a route through these landscapes. The carriages are new though, keeping the traditional wood-paneled style. Rural will turn to dramatic once again as you ride all the way to Middlemarch. From here, it will only be a short road transfer to Queenstown, where you will gaze upon Lake Wakatipu and have a chance to explore one of the country’s finest dining scenes.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Free Day to Explore the Queenstown Landscape
dayInfo.description: The Remarkables will rise to your North and West as snow remains on their alpine slopes year-round. If you gaze out westwards, you will be in Lord of the Rings territory, which are surreal landscapes that you will recognize from the big screen. Located behind you will be another domineering mountain, but this one will be reachable by a hiking trail or gondola. Today will be left free, and there are many ways you can explore. You can go on a Lord of the Rings tour, ride a speed boat across the lake or river, check out the views from the mountain, or go skiing or snowboarding during winter. If you want to sit back and enjoy the alpine air, then you will be more than welcome to relax and spend the day however if that is the best fit for you.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Stunning Overnight Cruise on Doubtful Sound
dayInfo.description: As the mist rises, the cliffs will begin to show. Waterfalls will tumble down, mostly heard rather than seen. Gradually, the sun will break through, and Doubtful Sound will come into full view. It is a special place to see, and even more special when you wake up in the fjord. Getting to experience how the fjord changes throughout the day is the beauty of an overnight cruise. Just to reach any of the fjords will be at least a three-hour journey from Queenstown. They are located in remote and isolated places but are worth the journey. Milford Sound is the most famous and popular. Reaching Doubtful Sound will take longer, but will create a more private fjord experience. After following the shores of Lake Wakatipu by road, you must then cross Lake Manapouri by boat before traversing the Wilmot Pass in a jeep. You will set sail on a luxury vessel where bottlenose dolphins will become your neighbors. Their fins will join with penguins and seals as you travel deeper into the wilderness. On day nine, there will be an opportunity to kayak along the shoreline or to explore in a tender boat with a naturalist guide. Hearing the eerie nighttime silence will connect you to the fjord, and as you sleep the mist will roll in. After waking up in this strange place, you will have another half-day of cruising, and when the landscape is this unique, it is almost essential to have a second day on the water. You will be back in Queenstown by late afternoon, and there are superb restaurants near the lakeside promenade.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef – The Sublime Scenery of Te Wai Pounamu’s West Coast
dayInfo.description: It’s a full-day journey to Franz Josef. But what a journey! Higher and higher through the mountains you go, crossing alpine passes to Lake Wanaka before climbing higher to Lake Hawea. You can stop and inhale the alpine air, wander in native beech forests, immerse yourself in the World Heritage landscapes, and cross over the Southern Alps to the West Coast. Gushing waterfalls meet vast rainforests and snowy mountains on this side of Te Wai Pounamu. Waves crash onto rocky beaches, and it will seem the landscapes have turned upside down. Arriving in Franz Josef, you will be beside two glaciers, and as night falls you must check your photo roll to make sense of everything today’s journey has included.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef – Glacial Hot Pools and Glacier Heli hike
dayInfo.description: Three glacier icefalls tumble towards the town, and all of them will be beautifully illuminated on your helicopter flight. The helicopter will land on a glacier, where you will set off walking. Frozen pinnacles will drop like works of art as you admire the amazing ice sculptures that nature has crafted. Caves and crevices will reveal the Earth’s untamed power. This heli hike will kick up adrenaline and works your legs, so this afternoon, you will be able to rest your body in glacial hot pools, which are a haven of warming tranquility.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – The World Famous TranzAlpine Train
dayInfo.description: You will complete your journey around New Zealand’s South Island today. First, you will weave North across mountains and coastline to Greymouth. It is here where you will have lunch here and say goodbye to your guide before the TranzAlpine train whisks you away. From the West coast to the East coast, it is a 4 ½ hour journey. Mountains will give way to forests and then hills before the Canterbury Plains stretch out in their green glory. You will arrive back in Christchurch at 6:30pm, so there will be plenty of time for one final New Zealand dinner.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Departure
dayInfo.description: After two weeks in New Zealand, you will be transferred to the international airport for your outbound flight.

tourName: North Island New Zealand Tour: Cities to Volcanoes
placesVisited: Auckland, New Zealand
generalInfo: This 11-day tour is designed especially for the intrepid traveler who enjoys a blend of active exploration and relaxing time to explore on your own. Boasting a distinctive identity and charming culture, New Zealand holds a special place for those wishing to visit the Southern Hemisphere. From Auckland to Wellington, the North Island will be your playground as you visit the many places that keep visitors thrilled.

dayInfo.title: Auckland – The City of Sails
dayInfo.description: Like an Italy of the Southern Hemisphere, New Zealand's distinctive boot shape is divided by the Cook Straight and presents visitors with an abundance of outdoor recreation and beautiful landscapes. You will step into this world on your first day of this tour of the North Island. Upon your arrival at the main Auckland airport, a comfortable transfer will convey you from the outskirts of the city into the beating heart of the City of Sails. After settling in to your conveniently located hotel, you will have the remainder of the day to explore the scenic waterfront and downtown area.

dayInfo.title: Matauri Bay – Magic of the North Island
dayInfo.description: Due to its remote location, New Zealand was one of the last major islands to be inhabited as patterns of human settlement reached through Oceania. New Zealand is home to some of the world's most stunning natural beauty. Today, you will enjoy an up-close and personal look at this beauty as you depart Auckland and transfer to Matauri Bay. Along the way, you will enjoy stops at the pristine beaches, secret coves, and subtropical forests.

dayInfo.title: Matauri Bay – Through the Outback
dayInfo.description: The scenic contours of the New Zealand coastline will be yours to enjoy as you make the most of your time in this picturesque destination. Your accommodation will happily provide you with a menu of activities to choose from, including a breathtaking horseback ride through the windswept sand dunes, a sailing excursion on the waves, or a mineral treatment at the local spa if you are more inclined to have a relaxing day. Regardless of what you choose, today's adventure will be a way to add a touch of class to your stay.

dayInfo.title: Matauri Bay – Through the Coastal Skies
dayInfo.description: Today, you will wake up to your final full day in Mantauri. A stroll along the hotel patio will reveal stunning views of the Pacific Ocean, including Cape Brett and the Cavalli Islands. As the day continues, your views will only get better when you take to the skies for a guided helicopter tour. This tour will allow you to enjoy a bird's-eye view of the coastline and to catch glimpses of the Kerikeri Inlet, Takou Bay, Tapuataehi Bay, and the Purerua Peninsula.

dayInfo.title: Auckland – Departing Northland
dayInfo.description: After enjoying breakfast from your hotel staff, you will turn your back on the rugged coastal terrain of the Northland region and make you to Auckland. During your journey, you will have plenty of time to enjoy the lush forests and scenic beauty of New Zealand. A short stop in the village of Kerikeri will introduce you to some of the local fruit, orchards, and artisans who proudly display their wares. From meandering hiking trails to scenic national forests, there is plenty to see before you arrive in Auckland.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – Finding Your Rhythm
dayInfo.description: Your road trip will continue as you make your way from the warm embrace of Auckland to the lake district around Rotorua. After a delicious breakfast from your hotel staff, you will make your way to the Bombay hills before passing through the rolling hills of Matamata. Like drops of blue on a green landscape, you will soon pass the lakes district. By the time you arrive at Lake Tarawera, you will have the remainder of the day to relax with a good book, enjoy the panoramic views, or use the hotel's recreational gear.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – The RIng of Fire
dayInfo.description: Sitting atop the famous Ring of Fire, which stretches along the tectonic plates that surround the Pacific Ocean, New Zealand has no shortage of geologic evidence of its volcanic nature. Today, you will explore this volcanic side of the North Island as well as its indigenous culture of the Maori people on a Kapa Haka cultural show. This show will introduce you to the storytelling, song, and dance that distinguishes this group from others. Afterward, you will explore the thermally active landscape and witness how to prepare food using the heat that is emitted from volcanic vents.

dayInfo.title: Hawke's Bay – Arriving at Cape Kidnappers
dayInfo.description: Today, the landlocked serenity of the lakes region will be replaced with the stunning vistas of Napier and the bold expanse of land known as Cape Kidnappers. During your journey, you will be fully engulfed in a landscape that has been carved through the powerful forces of volcanic activity that still frequent this part of the world. Geysers, mud pits, and natural hot springs will offer you abundant opportunities to stop and enjoy the roadside attractions. Soon, you will arrive at the hospitable accommodations.

dayInfo.title: Hawke's Bay – The Fruits of the Volcanic Soil
dayInfo.description: Volcanic activity and fertile soil are often found in tandem as frequent eruptions over the ages have allowed plenty of opportunities for the rich mineral wealth of the Earth's interior to be spewed across the landscape. The area around Hawk's Bay is no exception, and today, you will be able to enjoy the fruits of this fertile soil on a tour and tasting at a local winery. Here, the rustic growers will happily reveal the secrets of their savory wine varieties.

dayInfo.title: Wellington – New Zealand's Breadbasket
dayInfo.description: With the agricultural views of yesterday's wine tour still floating through your imagination, you will embark for your final leg of this North Island Tour. This morning, you will make your way to the country's charming capital of Wellington. Before arriving at your accommodation, you will have plenty of opportunities to view the countryside. Your journey and transfer will lead you through the rolling countryside of the Manawatu region and past neat rows of vineyards and rustic villages. Upon arriving in the capital, you will have the remainder of the day at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Wellington – Departure
dayInfo.description: As you wake up to the vibrant and mellow spirit of Wellington that percolates through the capital city like a thick fog, you will wish that you could stay for another 11 days. To spend your final morning of this tour, you can stop by a local book shop or pay a visit to the film studios that helped produce hits, such as King Kong and Lord of the Rings . A stroll around the waterfront will be another excellent way to enjoy the beautiful panoramas of this city before making your way to the airport for your departing flight.

tourName: Off the Beaten Path Tour of New Zealand: Wild Places in Ten Days
placesVisited: Hokianga, Lake Aniwhenua, Raetihi, Whanganui National Park, Napier, Christchurch, Peel Forest, Hawke's Bay
generalInfo: On this luxurious, 10-day adventure, you will canoe down wilderness rivers, search for the real Middle Earth, immerse yourself in a Maori community, explore an art deco city, and discover the unfrequented far north. Handcrafted with private tours and transfers, this is a journey into destinations that bask in their authenticity. Instead of other visitors, you will uncover secluded New Zealand.

dayInfo.title: Hokianga – Ninety Mile Beach
dayInfo.description: After flying to Auckland, you will pass through customs and immigration before transferring on a domestic flight to Northland, which is New Zealand’s most tropical region. You should sit on the right side because this will provide you with stunning views over Ninety Mile Beach. After touching down, you will be greeted by a guide for a day of Pacific allure. Today will be customizable, and you can choose how far to travel on Ninety Mile Beach. You may want to drive a four-wheel drive vehicle along a long and flat stretch of sand. Your guide can also arrange a sailing trip around Northland, where you can discover a number of otherwise inaccessible beaches.

dayInfo.title: Hokianga – Exploring Waipoua Forest
dayInfo.description: Hokianga is an excellent base because you can travel in many directions. A trek in Waipoua Forest is an essential experience when exploring New Zealand’s far north. The rest of the day can be tailored to your interests with options to explore inland forests and trails or to stay out on the coast where Pacific views seem to extend for eternity. Sandboarding the enormous white dunes is another possible option. Hokianga will also introduce you to an old-world way of life. The working harbor is a meeting place for Maori and European cultures, and it will be fascinating to explore the contrasts and congruence from a boat.

dayInfo.title: Lake Aniwhenua – Maori Experiences
dayInfo.description: From Hokianga, you will indulge in a beautiful journey toward Cape Reinga before looping to the Eastern coast for a flight from Kerikeri to Auckland. You will land in New Zealand’s largest city before being transferred to Lake Aniwhenua, where the experience will be all about cultural connection. Most people know the Maori for their well-built stature and haka war dance. You will be hosted by a local whanau, or family, for an afternoon and evening of Maori tradition. Local guides will show you some secret spots around the lake, and you will be provided with the opportunity to go canoeing along the shoreline.

dayInfo.title: Raetihi – Old-World New Zealand
dayInfo.description: The journey to Raetihi will traverse North Island’s volcanic landscape. Thousands of conical hills shape the land. You will snake around one and be greeted by another and another until you can see nothing but green hills that are speckled white with sheep. This bucolic scenery will be followed by the old-world charm of Raetihi, which is a historic town that is home to a delightful spa and lodge. The afternoon and evening will be at your leisure, and it can be great to bask in some modern luxuries before you set off on the Whanganui River tomorrow.

dayInfo.title: Whanganui National Park – Wilderness Canoeing
dayInfo.description: The Whanganui River journey is one of New Zealand’s acclaimed Great Walks. It is not a walk, but a canoe trip through a wilderness that is inaccessible by road or on foot. The entire canoe trip covers over 90 miles, but you will not have the time for that. Instead, you will canoe a quiet, two-day section that is deep in the forest. You should note that this New Zealand itinerary can be customized to include more time on the river. You can also choose a three-day Whanganui River trip or combine the two and three-day options for a five-day expedition. There are no single day options because once you are on the river, it is at least two days to the next take out point.

dayInfo.title: Hawke's Bay – Endless Vineyards
dayInfo.description: After the great outdoors, you will return to some modern luxuries today. Your local guide will transfer you past a couple of iconic volcanoes to the pastoral valleys of Hawke's Bay. Napier sits at the heart of this vineyard country, and it is a wonderful city for a stroll. A tour of Napier will be complemented by wine tasting at a couple of Hawke's Bay vineyards. Almost all these wineries remain small-scale and boutique, so you can meet the owners and winemakers during your tasting. This evening, you will be staying amid the vines at a small Hawke's Bay vineyard.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Street Art Tour
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will have an early start as you board the first direct flight of the day between Hawke's Bay and Christchurch. Today, you will join a local artist for a private tour of Christchurch. Using wall murals as a focal point, you will tour different points from the earthquake and rubble. Clearing rubble is an enormous job, and you will see piles of broken buildings that are yet to be removed. Artists painted vibrant murals on the sides of ruined buildings; they injected color and life into the city, giving the city a pleasant aesthetic.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Into Middle-Earth
dayInfo.description: Today, you will explore Rangitata and Peel Forest, which are areas that have been featured in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and are as Middle-earth looking as anywhere in the country. Sharp peaks will provide you with a dramatic backdrop while undulating trails lead you on a 30-minute stroll or four-hour hike. Rangitata and Peel Forest showcase a quintessential New Zealand landscape, but they remain mostly unexplored because people venture elsewhere on the South Island. After a day spent outdoors, you will return to Christchurch for a second night in the city.

dayInfo.title: Christchurch – Departure
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, you will transfer to the airport and depart New Zealand directly from Christchurch.

tourName: Off the Beaten Track New Zealand Adventure
placesVisited: Bay of Islands, Cape Reinga, Taupo, Hawkes Bay, Westhaven Inlet, Wanaka
generalInfo: So much of New Zealand is so blissfully off the beaten track. This two-week tour will take you to many of the country’s most secret places and hidden destinations, where silence and adventure showcase a country untamed. You will be indulging in helicopter rides to active volcanoes, rafting through the private Maori land, escaping to remote vineyards, and hiking through the wilderness. Handpicked lodges elevate your sense of getting away from the crowds, and there will be many beautiful ways to explore this marvelous country.

dayInfo.title: Auckland to Bay of Islands – Cruising in Paradise
dayInfo.description: When you are battling with jet lag and travel fatigue, the best thing to do is to cruise. You can recline on the deck of a chartered yacht, feel a refreshing wind as it passes your ears, and gaze upon deserted islands. When the captain drops anchor, you can jump into beautiful Pacific waters or kayak to an isolated and uninhabited beach. To round off your introductory day, you will indulge in a picnic that will be complete with a bottle of sparkling champagne. So, rest, kick-back, and forget about planning anything. From the moment that you land in the Bay of Islands, there is not much that you need. An airport transfer will bring you to the harbor-side lodge, and your day can be as relaxed as you require.

dayInfo.title: Bay of Islands – Helicopter Tour to Cape Reinga and Rally Car Adventure
dayInfo.description: New Zealand’s Northern tip can be easily reached on a helicopter, and there is so much sand for the pilot to touch down. You will soar over Ninety Mile Beach and watch the forest roll beneath the propellers. Once at Cape Reinga, you will have a choice of adventure: You can accelerate around corners and kick up dust on a guided drive on part of the country’s world rally route, or drive yourself, kicking up sand on a tour across one of the world’s longest beaches. The helicopter will take you back to the Bay of Islands where a sunset dinner will be an indulgent affair.

dayInfo.title: Bay of Islands – More Sailing in the Wilderness
dayInfo.description: Hopefully by now, you will have completely let go, but you may still need a little time to completely adjust to the new time zone. This open day will be your chance to adjust with nothing but a bay, deserted islands, and a private yacht. With the wind in the sail, you can cruise to very remote areas where there are not even any other boats. You can also sail closer to the lodge, which is a shorter journey with plenty of stops to swim, snorkel, and drink wine with the setting sun. Like most days on this handcrafted tour, the exact timings will be customizable, so you can bend the day to your delights.

dayInfo.title: Taupo – Blackwater Cave Rafting or Abseiling in a Lost World
dayInfo.description: There are areas around Taupo that are not only off the beaten track but closed to visitors. These are traditional Maori lands, and you need special permission to gain access. Today, you will explore some of these lands with a senior Maori who will show you where to pray and how to fully respect the region. With no roads, you need a novel way to explore. You will go rafting in a cave, climb and abseil in a remote cove, and find secluded places that are mostly known only to the Maori.

dayInfo.title: Taupo – Active Volcano Heli-Hike
dayInfo.description: Today’s adventure will be just as remote. Volcanic cones stand sharply above Lake Taupo, and you will have been admiring throughout yesterday’s evening. They are active, spitting, and hissing strange colors from their craters. From a helicopter, you can appreciate this surreal and natural sight. The pilot will take you above and alongside three different volcanoes before you touch down and hike in this supreme wilderness. As you wander around a crater rim, the stark reality of this volcanic landscape will hit you. The Earth has a humbling power, and it is this that will enchant you most when walking along these volcanoes.

dayInfo.title: Hawkes Bay – Spa Relaxation at New Zealand’s Hidden Vineyards
dayInfo.description: After two very active days, Hawkes Bay will now give you some time to unwind. This is the least visited part of the country’s wine regions even though it produces some of the country’s best wines. Coming from Taupo, the landscape will flatten from mountains to rolling pastures and wine farms that line the cliffs. Few people come here, and the escapism can feel absolute. Your lodge is located on the cliffs. To one side, you can gaze out onto the Pacific while to the others you will be surrounded by vines. You will check-in to your detached suite, and your private plunge pool will be a great place to bask in these views. A private wine tasting will be arranged on your terrace, and the cellar master will give you the chance to try rare and old vintages. Over these two days, a private chef will customize your menu, and it is always fresh and seasonal produce with a certain flair and panache as well. Mostly, you can do nothing but indulge on the farm, down at the beach, and in the excellent on-site spa. If you need things to do, there can be activities on the water or around other vineyards. Some of the clifftop picnics can provide memories for eternity.

dayInfo.title: Nelson to Westhaven Inlet �– Cruising and Kayaking Abel Tasman National Park
dayInfo.description: Today, you will fly directly from Hawkes Bay to Nelson, where you will be greeted by a guide and transferred to Westhaven Inlet. Located on the Eastern side of Abel Tasman National Park, this small bay continues a sense of being cut off from the world. This afternoon will be all about the coastline itself with a private charter that will take you to turquoise coves and isolated places beneath the cliffs. Sharks and rays swarm in the tidal coves and are clearly visible in such pristine waters. To really get close to them, you can choose to go kayaking as well. Again, this activity will be tailored around you, so it could be 20 minutes or two hours of paddling.

dayInfo.title: Westhaven Inlet – Kahurangi Hiking Trails and Coastal Fishing
dayInfo.description: From Westhaven, you can easily explore both Abel Tasman and Kahurangi national parks. The coastal fishing is superb all along the coast, so this can be your primary option today. Kayaking and renting a charter boat are also options. The recommended afternoon activity is to explore some of Kahurangi’s remote mountain trails. Despite this being New Zealand’s second largest park, it is off the beaten track. Your guide knows some excellent little trails that can suit your fitness levels from riverine tracks to an ascent to remote high-country lakes and peaks.

dayInfo.title: Westhaven Inlet – A Safari Wilderness Tour
dayInfo.description: Mountains soar, rivers cut through indigenous forest, and strange birds tweet from the trees. This is a part of Kahurangi that is normally closed to the public, and it will be your destination for today. The only way around is in a four-wheel drive vehicle, and it can be quite a journey, surging over rivers and bumping onto deserted beaches along your way. You will enjoy a barbecue picnic by a river, feel the silence and solitude, and then explore some more of the park’s unknown trails. You will have another option for today. You can choose to go canyoning instead, which is a mix of abseiling, waterfalls, jumps, slides, and floating down a granite canyon.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown to Wanaka – The World’s Southernmost Wine Region
dayInfo.description: With a good flight connection, you can connect Nelson with Queenstown in just three hours. After soaring over the Southern Alps, you will land in New Zealand’s most touristic destination. A local guide will take you into Central Otago, which is the world’s Southernmost wine region, where you will visit a private winery for a private tasting with the owner. You will then stop for an opulent lunch on a terrace that overlooks the vines. Then, you can choose whether to make one or two more stops en route to Wanaka, which is where your lodge will be tucked away on the quietest side of the lake.

dayInfo.title: Wanaka – Horse Riding and Mountain Biking in Mt Aspiring National Park
dayInfo.description: Mountains rise majestically above Lake Wanaka, and they will be the focal point of today’s adventure. You can choose whether to horse ride, mountain bike, or hike in this national park. For all these options, your guide will first take you into the park by road, so there is no wasted time. With hiking and biking, the idea is that you will travel downhill to Wanaka although you can choose to add in a couple of climbs. Horse riding mostly sticks to the high country where there is space to gallop on open pastures. There is a vineyard that is located directly on Lake Wanaka, which can be a good choice for dinner tonight.

dayInfo.title: Wanaka – Helicopter and Kayaking in Fjordland
dayInfo.description: Fjordland is enormous. There are still large stretches of it that are an unknown. Tourists mostly visit Milford and Doubtful Sounds because these are the only two places that have been made accessible by road. This is a landscape of endless mountains, valleys, fjords, and lakes. Your guide will be a former Fjordland hunter and helicopter pilot. He knows this landscape better than anyone and will design a full day’s tour that is based on the type of landscapes that you want to see. With propellers blurring, you can cruise through fjords and land on remote plateaus. It will be possible to cross snow-capped peaks and to touch down on unseen beaches where ocean waters rush into the fjords.

dayInfo.title: Wanaka to Queenstown – Departure
dayInfo.description: Queenstown’s popularity is a good thing, and today you will depart from the renovated international airport. It is a 60-minute transfer from Wanaka, but you can allow more time for viewpoint and winery stops.

tourName: Outdoor Tour of New Zealand: Best of the North Island in 2 Weeks
placesVisited: Auckland, Waiheke Island, Thames, Coromandel, Whangamata, Rotorua, Lake Taupo
generalInfo: Kayaking to Whenuakura and crossing Tongariro will be just two of the experiential highlights on this adventurous 14-day excursion of New Zealand’s outdoors. New Zealand’s North Island is the great outdoors: it is a magnificent land of rugged mountains, rolling coastline, bucolic pastures, and volcanic enchantment. From digging a jacuzzi in the sand to Maori encounters and sailing through the Pacific with dolphins, these two weeks will showcase the very best of the North Island’s wild side.

dayInfo.title: Auckland – Introduction to the Capital
dayInfo.description: Auckland’s city charm is created by quirky little neighborhoods, and the city center is not overly impressive, especially if you are more of an outdoor person. The small neighborhoods can feel like little villages with lovely cafes, boutiques, bars, and artistic architecture, and after a private airport transfer, this day will be at your leisure. Auckland’s neighborhoods are relaxing and comfortable places to get over your jet lag and become accustomed to the New Zealand pace of life. You can also take a stroll around the harbor to check out some pop-up bars and watch all the boats.

dayInfo.title: Auckland – Whale and Dolphin Safari
dayInfo.description: Auckland has more boats per capita than any other city on the planet. They love sailing here, and there is no better introduction to the North Island than cruising on the water. Dolphins play in the wake of boats with their fins rising and falling in a form of marine poetry. Whales can also be seen in these waters, especially when you sail further into the Pacific. Today’s private catamaran tour will search for these marine creatures, but the real highlight will be the actual sailing. You can sail fast on these waters, and you do not need to use the engine. The captain can lead you to deserted beaches and uninhabited islets in addition to helping you follow all the dolphin fins.

dayInfo.title: Waiheke Island – Vineyards and Beaches
dayInfo.description: Your two weeks on the North Island will feature a ton of hiking and outdoor activities. These two days will be at your leisure, and with all your adventures still to come, Waiheke is an excellent place to completely overcome the jet lag and allow the stress of home to drift away. Of course, this is New Zealand, so you will still be outdoors most of the time. Hiking trails connect vineyards with beaches, so you can do some tasting before an afternoon on the sand. Other trails can lead you to hidden coves and tiny pools that are perfect for swimming. You can also have tapas and wine on the hill at Casita Miro before enjoying a lively evening on Onetangi Beach.

dayInfo.title: Thames – Exploring the Wilderness
dayInfo.description: After taking an early ferry back to the mainland, you will be met by a private guide for a North Island expedition. Your first stop will be Piha Beach, where the surf is superb, and the sense of wilderness will be an indication of things to come. Nikau glowworm caves will be your next destination, and they are far less popular than Waitomo. Unfortunately, Waitomo glowworm caves have turned into something of a tourist factory with tour buses that ship in groups all day long. Nikau is just as impressive but without the crowds. Afterward, Karangahake Gorge offers a wonderful, one-hour hike that you can choose to do, but if you are not feeling up to it, your guide will lead you straight to Owharoa Falls.

dayInfo.title: Thames – Hiking to the Pinnacle Rock Formations
dayInfo.description: Today, you will have a full-day hike to the Pinnacle Rock Formations. By traversing along the Webb Creek Trail, you will cross a series of narrow suspension bridges and find small waterfalls that are located deep within the forest. Most of the trail is shaded, but it is exposed to the sun after Pinnacles Hut, which will be the final 45 minutes of your journey. This section offers spectacular views of the surrounding valleys, and these will only get better when you reach the summit and admire the 360-degree panorama. Although this hike can be divided into two days with a night in a mountain hut, by doing it in one day, you should have the summit mostly to yourself.

dayInfo.title: Coromandel Peninsula – Relaxing on the Northern Beaches
dayInfo.description: After two active days, you will travel north along highway 25 to the Coromandel Peninsula, which is a destination that is dominated by spacious beaches and beautiful coastal tracks. Today will be customizable, and there is plenty you can do, including kayaking along the coast and hiking to a deserted cove for a picnic. The North Island beaches are famously clean and never busy, especially those in lesser-known areas like Coromandel. Trails wind through the trees and connect to different beaches, usually via a stunning, coastal viewpoint. Your guide will outline your options for the day, and you can also spend it lazing around your waterside hotel.

dayInfo.title: Whangapoua – Building Your Own Jacuzzi
dayInfo.description: Today will start with a slow and winding drive from Coromandel to Whangapoua, and you will be provided with the opportunity to stop at viewpoints and small farm stalls along the way. Your time of departure will depend on the tide because there is only a four-hour window to fully enjoy Hot Water Beach. Getting to this long beach first involves a 30-minute walk through the forest and along a stretch of coastal rocks. It is nice to enjoy the serenity here because Hot Water Beach is popular, and you will not have it all to yourself. A volcanic hot spring runs beneath the sand, and your guide will give you a shovel, so you can dig your own natural jacuzzi on the beach within a few meters of the rolling surf.

dayInfo.title: Whangamata – Kayaking to Whenuakura Island
dayInfo.description: You will continue your journey along the North Island coastline, winding through nature on a private transfer that will be followed by hiking and kayaking. The hike to Cathedral Cove is easy, and after walking through a cave, you will exit to a hidden beach and cove, where the vistas are a surreal assortment of rocky mountains that look as if they have been cast adrift by the ocean. This Cathedral Cove experience is best early in the morning, and an early start also means that you can fully enjoy your afternoon at Whangamata. From this small town, you will kayak to Whenuakura and follow an estuary into the heart of the island. The tide will push you inland to a lagoon of phantasmagorical color, and after this afternoon island experience, your evening will be relaxing and comfortable along the coast at another of New Zealand’s boutique hotels.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – Hobbiton Movie Set Tour
dayInfo.description: Hobbiton is an iconic North Island experience that showcases a different side to the outdoors. Although the movie set is artificial, Peter Jackson chose the location because nothing artificial can be seen in any direction. It can seem strange to pass through this part of New Zealand and not partake in the Hobbiton tour, but if you do not have any interest in Lord of the Rings, your guide can lead you along the coast to Mount Maunganui instead. A one-hour up and down hike will provide you with spectacular Pacific views from the summit, and the nearby town has some charming cafes that you can try for lunch. Rotorua will be today’s final destination, and you will be able to sense its volcanic history from the moment that you check into your luxury accommodation.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – Maori Cultural Experience
dayInfo.description: The Maori settled into Rotorua because of its natural underground energy, and the town continues to be at the heart of Maori culture. This evening, you will be greeted by a Maori community in the traditional manner, which can initially be a rather frightening experience. Do not worry because you will be in no harm whatsoever. After the welcome, everything will calm down, and you will spend the evening inside a Maori meeting place, watching some song and dance before a hangi dinner is roasted for you underground on volcanic rocks. The rest of your day will be fully customizable, and there are endless possibilities as to what you can do outdoors around Rotorua.

dayInfo.title: Lake Taupo – Hiking Rainbow Mountain
dayInfo.description: Today, you will travel to Rainbow Mountain, which can be reached via a tramping trail. After hiking, you can descend into a crater of azure water before visiting a string of waterfalls. These waterfalls near Rainbow Mountain have hot water, so you can bathe in hot springs above and below the cascades. You will then venture to Wai-O-Tapu, which is another geothermal wonderland that features New Zealand’s most iconic geyser. Single-track mountain bike trails can lead you through the indigenous rainforest just like they can near Rotorua, and you can also go sailing on the lake. There is skydiving, bungee jumping, and so much more close to Lake Taupo, and today will be completely flexible, so you can do more activities closer to Rotorua or leave early for a full afternoon in Taupo.

dayInfo.title: Lake Taupo – The Tongariro Alpine Crossing
dayInfo.description: An iconic, one-way hike around the North Island’s most majestic volcano, the Tongariro Alpine Crossing is a world-famous highlight of New Zealand. It is a challenging, guided hike, and will take all day, but with the effort comes reward because you will hike past volcanic pools and soda springs before reaching the crater rim. After summiting Red Crater and enjoying the Emerald Lakes, you will descend to Blue Lake and then all the way down along a narrow and rocky trail. It will be spectacular, and you will have stunning views of the North Island throughout your journey.

dayInfo.title: Taupo to Auckland – Departure
dayInfo.description: From Taupo, you will fly to Auckland and connect with your outbound flight.

tourName: Pokémon​ Inspired Family Tour to Australia & New Zealand
placesVisited: Auckland, Queenstown, Rotorua, Milford Sound, Melbourne, Port Douglas, Great Barrier Reef, Kuranda, Sydney
generalInfo: Does someone in your family have Pokémon fever? This Pokémon-inspired family tour of Australia and New Zealand is perfect for families who want to see it all and catch em' all. Embrace the opportunity to turn this family vacation into a breathtaking and educational experience the whole family will never forget. Take the kids' Pokémon pursuit to the next level and have them experience the exhilarating feeling of exploring new lands and capturing regionally exclusive rare Pokémon such as Kangaskhan, which can only be found in Australia and New Zealand. Spend a day or two having them lead the family through the vibrant Great Barrier Reef and the serene Milford Sound in search of Pokémon in foreign lands; your private tour guide (who is also a Pokémon fan!) is able to expertly educate the family on the historical and cultural significance of the destinations you venture to.

dayInfo.title: Auckland – The Beauty of New Zealand
dayInfo.description: Arrive in Auckland and watch the city’s many sails flutter into view. The Sky Tower, the largest building in the Southern Hemisphere, ascends over the city and adds to the majesty of Auckland’s skyline. Jump into the adventure and explore Auckland Harbour on a harbor cruise. The skyline drifts into the distance as you float under the skeletal structure of the Auckland Bridge, the salty smell of the sea in the air, and the clear turquoise of the sea beneath you. Wave to the numerous lush islands that pass in the distance, some full of quaint towns and antique shops, others uninhabited and great for hiking. As the sun sets on the horizon, Auckland glimmers in the city lights that reflect on the shoreline.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – A Light in the Dark
dayInfo.description: On your way from Auckland to Rotorua, you will stop at the Waitomo Caves to experience the brilliance of the Glowworm Grotto . Drift on the river, deeper into the cave where the light of glowworms speckles the darkness in green and gold light dangling from the ceiling. Continue to Rotorua, the Maori cultural capital of New Zealand. Witness the power and intimidation of a Haka , the traditional Maori war dance. The dancers’ voices scream out as they slap their chests, stick out their tongues, bulge out their eyes, and remind you how good it is not to be the opposing army. The air smells of roasted lamb and sweet potatoes from the hangi , a traditional Maori barbecue buried in the ground. The meat is succulent, and the vegetables are tender, an incredible meal to end a marvelous day.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – Discover the Depths of Middle Earth
dayInfo.description: Indulge in Rotorua, New Zealand’s cultural capital. Start the day with a trip to the Maori Arts and Crafts Institute, created to preserve Maori’s cultural and artistic traditions. Take a peek at the Wood Carving School, where local students learn how to record and preserve the history of their people. Similar carvings can be seen around New Zealand in Maori centers: meeting houses, canoes, weapons and jewelry, the finer the carving, the more prestigious the item. Afterward, venture to the depths of Middle Earth as you enter the Shire, found in Hobbiton. Visit the subterranean homes of Frodo, Samwise, Pippin, Merry, and Bilbo as you explore the breathtaking scenery with a private guide who will take you behind the scenes and beyond the expanding hobbit-hills. Consider enjoying a picnic lunch from The Green Dragon and indulge in basket overflowing with hobbit essentials such as honey-glazed ham, assorted local cheeses, homemade pork pie, vegetables from the local garden, freshly baked bread, a bottle of wine, and juice. Enjoy your meal underneath the shade of the tree overlooking the lake, amidst the verdant meadows. Inside the Green Dragon Inn, a fire roars from the fireplace, producing a lingering scent of charred timber.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – A Queenstown Welcome
dayInfo.description: Depart Rotorua for beautiful Queenstown, an incredible lakeside town on the South Island. Settled on the shores of Lake Wakatipu, the surrounding majestic Remarkables Range reflects in the pristine water. Take advantage of all Queenstown has to offer, no matter the season. The air is cool and crisp. Boats sail on the lake and laughter floats through the air. Take the Southern Hemisphere’s steepest gondola ride to the top of Bob’s Peak. Sit in comfort as all of Queenstown and Lake Wakatipu unfold before you as you ascend almost into the clouds, with New Zealand sitting at your feet.

dayInfo.title: Milford Sound – Serene Milford Sound
dayInfo.description: A cruise through Milford Sound will remind you of how magnificent New Zealand’s natural wonders can be. The air smells of crisp, pure seawater. The water is pearl blue and cold to the touch. Mountains climb and sprawl around the sound with trees clinging to cliff faces and roots holding fast to the sediment. Stand at the rail and watch the waterfalls careen down the mountains splashing elegantly into the water, mist rising and filling the air with a mixture of sea and melted snow. Listen to the barking of Fur Seals and the yipping of dolphins that call the sound their home. No matter the season, Milford Sound has an unspoiled and unparalleled beauty; exploring Milford Sound is a wonderful and fitting way to spend your final day in New Zealand.

dayInfo.title: Melbourne – Australia Calling
dayInfo.description: Transfer to the Queenstown Airport and say goodbye to the incredible natural wonders of New Zealand. Fly over the frigid, still beauty of the Tasman Sea on your way to Melbourne, Australia. Melbourne is the cultural center of Australia, known for its art, food, street culture, and boutique shops. The bells of streetcars peal in the air as the echo of heels thump on the cobblestone walkways. There is no shortage of nooks to explore while in Melbourne, where on many streets the smell of fresh pastries emanates from hidden alleyways. A walk through Fitzroy will bring you to the Bohemian center of the city, where the incense of second-hand shops mixes with the lavish perfume of designer stores. Fitzroy is a wonderful place to wander and wonder.

dayInfo.title: Melbourne – Natural Melbourne
dayInfo.description: You will get to experience some of Australia's friendliest residents at the Moonlit Sanctuary Wildilfe Conservation Park, an eco-certified sanctuary that is home to endangered native species such as the Southern Bettong, Eastern Quolls, and Fluffy Gliders. If seeing a koala is on your list, visit the Koala Conservation Centre for a face to face experience with one of Australia's most adorable creatures. Then make your way to Summerland beach for the world-famous nightly penguin parade, and watch the hundreds of small penguins waddle across the beach as they make their way back home. Indulge in a tour of tasty treats at Panny’s Chocolate Factory on Phillip Island. Enjoy the rich taste of Panny’s “Secret Recipe” white truffle upon your arrival, a delectable and luxurious introduction of the tour to come. Full of interactive machines to experiment with, Panny’s is practically the Willy Wonka of Melbourne. Full of chocolate fun and facts, don’t forget to take advantage of making your own chocolate on the tour, rich or sweet, dark or white, as you perfect your own chocolate according to your tastes. To complete the day on a tasty note, try dinner at Golden Fields, an Asian Fusion restaurant in the St. Kilda district. Set on mixing Asian flavors with international palates, the chef’s interpretation of a lobster roll is made with the decadence of local, poached crayfish and Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise; a memorable meal for an unforgettable day.

dayInfo.title: Port Douglas – Journey North
dayInfo.description: Depart Melbourne for the northern delights of Port Douglas, Australia, and the enchanting beauty of the Great Barrier Reef. Wander along the Esplanade and the sea-salt lagoon that decorates the walkway. Metal fish fly in through the air; people splash through the water, ankle deep, as the sun settles warmly in the sky, making the cool water a welcome escape.

dayInfo.title: Great Barrier Reef – Cruising the Reef
dayInfo.description: Cruise to the edge of the continental shelf and explore the underwater world of the Great Barrier Reef. The blend of pink coral, orange fish, and purple anemones swirl together under the magnifier of clear water. Watch the world from the dry comforts of a glass-bottom boat or dive into the water and watch the hidden gems of the world up close. The giant clam of Agincourt’s exterior makes people mistake the mollusk as coral; its mouth drifts apart, revealing its almost neon purple and blue streaked insides. If you’re lucky, you may see the gentle magnitude of a whale shark as it floats along the reef, its wide mouth and spotted skin meandering through the water in a calm and passive manner. As the sun sets, the reef almost glows in the darkening orange, seemingly setting the water on fire.

dayInfo.title: Kuranda – From Seas to Trees
dayInfo.description: Journey from the pearl-blue water to the lush green rainforest on the Kuranda Railway. One of the most scenic railways in the world, you will travel through hand-hewn tunnels and across open bridges while the luster of the rainforest extends out for as far as the eye can see. Barron Falls sprawls over the edge of the mountain and thunders down into the valley below, mist rising from the rapids and filling the air with damp forest. View the falls from the comforts of the train-car or from the viewing platform where you can feel the mist rising from the valley below. The train stops in Kuranda, a forest town full of antique shops and Aboriginal culture. Set in the seclusion the rainforest offers, Kuranda is a combination of eccentric local character and the natural wonders of its surroundings. For those looking to take to the skies for unparalleled views of the visually stunning region, the Skyrail rainforest gondola is a breathtaking family adventure attraction. The truly adventurous can upgrade their tour to have a glass floor or even a full 360-degree open-air gondola, for a truly immersive rainforest experience. Or consider paying a visit to the Butterfly Sanctuary (the largest in Australia), where you can stand amidst nature as it flutters around you. Be sure to walk along the wooded path so that the butterflies can flit around you, often landing on people’s shoulders and hands when held steady. The Ulysses Swallowtail has bright blue wings with black tips that flutter so fast, it’s like a blue strobe light darting past you in the brush. Learn about the butterflies' lifecycles and their inhabitation of Australia. At the Butterfly Sanctuary, you don’t just see the exhibit; you are a part of it.

dayInfo.title: Sydney – Northern Trees to Southern Sails
dayInfo.description: Depart Queensland for Sydney, Australia and watch the sails of the Sydney Opera House come into view as the plane descends. The city by the sea contains all that Australia has become known for, including beaches, cuisine, and a city of international cosmopolitanism. Venture through the neighborhoods to experience the local delights. Newtown is home to Sydney’s largest concentration of artists, along with galleries, studios, and shops. The streets practically smell of fresh paint and imagination as you wander the neighborhood and run into shops like All Buttons Great and Small, a store dedicated to the collection and selling of all types of buttons. Almost like a museum, the store offers and creates various outlets for its buttons, including incredible displays. If the sea is calling your name, then head to the Sydney highlights of either Bondi Beach or Manly Beach, where people from all over the world come to relax. Or if the children are looking to complete their animal sightseeing checklist, consider a visit to the Taronga Zoo, home to 4,000 animals of 340 species.

dayInfo.title: Sydney – Inside the Harbour
dayInfo.description: Look around and inside the sails that decorate the Sydney Harbour. Experience the Sydney Opera House with a tour of more than just the outside Esplanade. The outside looks like a ship, with bright white, wide sails ready to float into the sea at any moment. The inside of the Opera House looks like a gilded clam, layered and ornate, with acoustics that can make a whisper echo throughout the chamber. The journey through Sydney Harbour continues with a cruise on the water. Surf along the waterfront with the sails of the Opera House shrinking in the distance, while the skeletal frame of the Harbour Bridge looms overhead; Sydney’s skyline dims to a distant silhouette in the sun. Watch the seaside houses peek from the tree line and decorate the shores of Sydney’s waterway suburbs. The smell of coffee from the boat mixes with the sea and the smoke of barbecues on the shore. The sun sets as the lights of the skyline shine bright and calls you back to land.

dayInfo.title: Sydney – Sydney’s Natural Surroundings
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, your guide will meet you in the hotel lobby to take you to one of Sydney's most famous sites, the Greater Blue Mountains, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This visually stunning region is aptly named after the intense blue haze that results from the mixture of the droplets of oil produced by Eucalyptus trees combined with dust particles and water vapor. On the way, make a stop at Sydney’s award-winning Featherdale Wildlife Park, known for its conservation efforts and an incredible collection of Australia’s unique fauna. Cassowaries look practically prehistoric in their size, similar to an ostrich. The males are colorful with deep-blue skin around their neck and a Mohawk-topped proudly on their heads, while Kookaburras are famous for their territorial squawk that sounds like a high-pitched laugh ringing through the trees. Enjoy the fluffy cuddles of a koala as it slowly wraps its paws around your shoulders. Snap a photo so everyone at home will believe you had the chance to cuddle the herbivorous marsupial. Linger among the kangaroos as they lounge in the shade, shielding themselves from the sun. On your last day in Australia, you can reach out and touch the continent, like the continent has no doubt touched you.

dayInfo.title: Sydney – On Your Way
dayInfo.description: You will transfer to the Sydney Airport to depart back home. Though the trip has ended, there will be plenty of time to reminisce, thoughts of the mountain ranges that hovered within the clouds, the smells of the hangi , the sounds of the haka , the colors of the Reef, and the cuddly fur of the koala. The trip has ended but the memories never will. Note: Zicasso and “Pokémon Inspired Family Tour to Australia & New Zealand” are not affiliated with, or sponsored or endorsed by, The Pokémon Company International, Pokémon Korea Inc., Niantic Inc., Google Inc., Alphabet Inc., ©Nintendo, ©GAME FREAK Inc. and ©Creatures Inc.

tourName: Premier New Zealand South Island Tour: Natural and Cultural Gems
placesVisited: Queenstown, Wanaka, Mt. Aspiring National Park, Franz Josef Glacier, Abel Tasman National Park, Blenheim, Kaikoura
generalInfo: Packed full of thrilling activities and staggering landscapes, this is the ultimate two-week itinerary for nature lovers on New Zealand’s South Island. This tour leads you from outdoor adventure on the South Island to the highest mountain and the deepest fjord. It features whales, icebergs, jet boats, kayaks, hikes, helicopters, and so much more. Book your adventure today.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Settling in on the South Island
dayInfo.description: Queenstown is the obvious place to begin an outdoor adventure on the South Island. It is the main hub for activities and the stepping stone for exploring Fiordland National Park. While there is a lot to do here, Queenstown’s laid-back atmosphere is also ideal for relaxing after a long flight. Your driver will greet you at the airport and transfer you to your accommodation in the heart of the city. The rest of today will be at your leisure so that you can rest before the real adventure starts.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Boat Ride and Vineyard Excursion
dayInfo.description: Zooming down a narrow canyon, a jet boat pilot will take you remarkably close to stark walls. Today, you will have a thrilling ride on a jet boat. You will also ride with the original jet boat company, which is the only company that is permitted to do 360-degree spins on the river. Jet boating will get your heart pumping in addition to illustrating the wild beauty of the South Island. In the afternoon, you can calm down with a guided visit to a Central Otago vineyard. This experience will include wine tasting and sublime views.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Your Choice of Outdoor Activities
dayInfo.description: Queenstown is a great travel base. Today will be left free so that you can customize your itinerary with your choice of outdoor activities. Queenstown is home to three bungee jumps and two bungee swings, including the world’s first commercial bungee jump. Kayaks and mountain bikes will help you explore Queenstown’s surroundings. You can paraglide off Bob’s Peak, go skiing in the winter, or take a Lord of the Rings tour to Glenorchy. There are also dozens of superb walking trails. Today will be tailored exactly to your interests in one of the world’s most majestic settings.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Milford Sound by Boat and Helicopter
dayInfo.description: Crossing over mountain passes, you will travel through Fiordland National Park this morning. Eventually, you will arrive at Milford Sound. This is the deepest and narrowest of all the fjords. Milford Sound is a mesmerizing work of nature that you will explore on an afternoon cruise. Waterfalls tumble hundreds of feet from the fjord’s walls, mist swirls to create an added layer of wonder, and dolphins patrol the water. When departing, you will fly back to Queenstown by helicopter and stop on a glacier to walk amid ice sculptures. For Fiordland, this immersion is the ultimate single-day experience.

dayInfo.title: Wanaka – Mountain Biking around the Lake
dayInfo.description: After a one-hour private transfer to Wanaka, you will settle in for two days alongside the lakeside. Wanaka is quiet and picturesque, making it an idyllic base for mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking in South Island’s national parks. Today, you will explore on two wheels with a guide, cycling one of the world’s greatest network of single-track trails. There is something for every level, so you can choose the daring downhills or something a little smoother. Plus, a vehicle will be available to take you and your bike uphill.

dayInfo.title: Wanaka – Mt. Aspiring National Park
dayInfo.description: Today, you can kayak on the lake to a small island with its own spa. This planned activity will be to visit Mt. Aspiring National Park and to try one of the hiking trails. Like yesterday, there will be various options, so your guide will tailor a program to your interests. One particular hike can take you along a winding trail, through indigenous forest, and over a peak to a plateau that is cut off from the rest of the world. Afterward, you can return most of the way on a river raft.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef Glacier – South Island Road Trip
dayInfo.description: Wanaka to Franz Josef Glacier is a wonderful journey. Countless lakes and viewpoints line the road, and you will traverse two national parks on a route that is entirely within the Te Wahipounamu UNESCO World Heritage Site. After a morning on the road, you can get close with kiwis at a small rescue center, which is known for providing encounters with the flightless birds. Your hotel offers views of the glaciers and forests, so you may start to get excited about your glacier hike tomorrow.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef Glacier – Walking across a Glacier
dayInfo.description: The glacier of Franz Josef (not the town with the same name) is only accessible by helicopter. You will begin the trip by soaring to the top of the glacier and then wandering across the ice in crampons. Icy-blue tunnels and artistic-like sculptures cover the landscape, making it feel like you are walking in a version of Narnia. Down below, the forest extends, and you can admire how the glacier crashes through the trees. This is one of South Island’s most iconic outdoor experiences, and you cannot rival the feeling of exploring such an endless sheet of ice.

dayInfo.title: Franz Josef Glacier – Helicopter to Mt. Cook and Icebergs
dayInfo.description: Mt. Cook soars high above the town, but you cannot really see it or access it by road. The only way to get there is by helicopter. So, you will indulge in a full-day private helicopter tour of Mt. Cook National Park. You will soar above New Zealand’s highest peaks before touching down next to a glacial lake. Here, there are icebergs that float in turquoise-hued waters, and you can cruise alongside them, admiring how every iceberg is an entirely different shape. Returning by helicopter will provide you with more stunning views, including one of the rugged coastline.

dayInfo.title: Abel Tasman National Park – Kayak into the Wilderness
dayInfo.description: A private transfer to Abel Tasman National Park will complete your journey along the South Island’s West Coast, from fjords and canyons to cliffs and tropical colors. Your accommodation will only be accessible by water or hiking trail, so you will need a boat transfer to your lodge. This afternoon, a local guide will help you explore the coastline. Kayaks are the preferred mode of outdoor adventure here. By paddling into coves and coastal caves, you can encounter rays, dolphins, and surreal cliff formations. Like elsewhere, activities will be flexible and customizable.

dayInfo.title: Abel Tasman National Park – Tropical Adventures
dayInfo.description: Abel Tasman deserves at least two days because there are some incredible cliffside hiking trails. There are also islands that can only be visited by boat or kayak. Abel Tasman is a national park that is home to the South Island’s best beaches, so today may be a day to kick back and enjoy some downtime. Dolphins patrol these shores, and you may spot them from your accommodation. There are self-guided hiking trails you can take to nearby beaches, and there is nothing like a sunset paddle in the lushest corner of New Zealand.

dayInfo.title: Blenheim – Cruising with Dolphins
dayInfo.description: After a short boat ride along the coast, you will transfer privately to Marlborough Sounds. This landscape is completely different from Milford Sound, and with a two-week South Island itinerary, you get the opportunity to compare these contrasting feats of nature. Marlborough is greener, broader, and framed by small islets. There are also many more dolphins. You will enjoy a half-day cruise before settling in to a vineyard lodge in the Marlborough wine region, which is the perfect place to catch your breath after some adventurous activities across the island.

dayInfo.title: Kaikoura – New Zealand’s Finest Whale Watching
dayInfo.description: It is less than two hours by road to Kaikoura, which is a harborfront town that has a great view of local sperm whales. A two-mile-deep ocean channel runs past Kaikoura, and it is a haven of food for the whales, who stay year-round. Humpback and southern right whales also pass by to enjoy this abundance, and blue whale sightings are not unusual. You will spend the afternoon savoring whale encounters on a small boat cruise with conservationist guides. This is a charming place to spend the night and do what you need to do before tomorrow’s long journey home.

dayInfo.title: Kaikoura – Departure
dayInfo.description: From Kaikoura, you will transfer to Christchurch and the South Island’s major international airport for your flight home.

tourName: Private New Zealand Tour: Couples Adventure
placesVisited: Kerikeri, Hobbiton, Rotorua, Hawkes Bay, Akaroa, Queenstown, Glenorchy, Doubtful Sound
generalInfo: You will find private places that are dotted all around New Zealand, where you can luxuriate in wilderness settings and surround yourself with open space. Dream of a tropical beach retreat, vineyards that are perched above Pacific cliffs, the soporific Canterbury plains, and dramatic mountain landscapes that have been cut off from the world. These hidden places will be the amorous settings for your exclusive ten-day tour, and these are the places in which New Zealand unfolds in all its wild and romantic majesty.

dayInfo.title: Kerikeri – Waterside Bliss in the Remote Bay of Islands
dayInfo.description: Kerikeri is a tropical place to start, where you can dip your feet into Pacific surf and feel an ocean breeze pass your ears. It is lush and blue up here, with golden beaches that stretch endlessly beneath your clifftop accommodation. After a short transfer from Auckland, you will fly to Kerikeri where it will be a short transfer to your exclusive, waterside accommodation. A small path can take you down to a beach that is almost always devoid of other people. Other paths lead along the cliffs to beautiful places that you can visit, especially around sunset. Nothing will be planned for you today, so you can check-in, admire the view, and settle into your private accommodation.

dayInfo.title: Kerikeri – Exclusive Heli Tour to Cape Reinga and Ninety Mile Beach
dayInfo.description: You will start with a leisurely breakfast on your verandah this morning. You can look out on the Pacific and sense its eternal allure. Birds will flutter past and chirp their morning call, but most importantly, there will be no other people. Kerikeri is not on most itineraries, and your hotel is set in its own enormous grounds. Privacy is paramount, and Kerikeri can give off the atmosphere of a tropical island retreat. After a leisurely morning, you will fly to New Zealand’s most Northern point. The helicopter will first take you across the vast expanse of Ninety Mile Beach. The sand extends to nothing but paradise beneath the propellers. Finally, you will land close to the country’s tip where you can walk past massive Kauri trees and sense the mystique of a forest that is located on the edge of the world. Rocky pinnacles start to appear, and soon, you will be at Cape Reinga, gazing Northward across one of the most majestic oceans. On your return journey to Kerikeri, there will be an opportunity to land on the beach and take a stroll in the sandy wilderness. Then, back at your hotel, a private dinner will be served on your verandah just as sunset sends saturated colors across the panorama.

dayInfo.title: Rotorua – Hobbit Holes and Meeting the Maori
dayInfo.description: After flying back to Auckland, you will spend today traveling by road on a privately chauffeured journey that weaves through idyllic farmland. The North Island is dominated by peculiar, volcanic hills and incredibly narrow valleys that help to create an idea of Middle Earth. It is a land that has been cut off from everything, and this is where Hobbiton is located. Here, you can have some private time at the untouched movie set before another 90-minute transfer South to Rotorua, which is home of the Maori. A Maori family will officially welcome you into their country, and it will be a beautiful ceremony. While their customs can initially seem dramatic, these friendly people are full of smiles, especially when you are welcomed into their meeting place for a traditional hangi dinner. For your meal, the food will be roasted underground on natural thermals with local lamb and other local delicacies.

dayInfo.title: Hawkes Bay – Vineyards, Private Picnics, and Spa Treatments
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will continue the dreamy impressions of New Zealand scenery as you transfer South to the wild and remote Hawkes Bay. Vineyards extend toward the cliffs here, and the valleys flatten a little when compared to yesterday, but the sense of wild escapism is enhanced, especially as you check into a vineyard lodge that overlooks the Pacific. Your suite will be surrounded by vines and features a private jacuzzi from which to toast to your vacation. A private wine tasting will introduce you to Hawkes Bay flavors before there is a private dinner on your deck. This is a place of silence and solitude, and nothing specific has been planned for these two days. Your accommodation can arrange picnic baskets and show you places to dine upon the cliffs. The hotel spa can entice at all hours of the day, and a couple’s treatment is included in your package. Then, there is the infinity pool and many thousands of acres of rolling pastures. If you really fancy an adventure, then it will be possible to walk hand in hand upon the cliffs and then down to a beach that is always clear of other footprints. Hawkes Bay is one of New Zealand’s remote and special places, and it is a destination that remains a long way from standard visitor itineraries. It is also a place that has been made just for two, and you can spend 48 hours of luxuriating in each other’s company.

dayInfo.title: Akaroa – Romantic Tranquility on the Rugged South Island
dayInfo.description: From soporific North Island pastures to striking South Island landscapes, you will switch settings this morning. After flying from Hawkes Bay to Christchurch, your guide will transfer you one-hour South to Akaroa, which is where the hills tumble into a turquoise, dolphin-filled bay. You will check into a farm on the Banks Peninsula, which will be a delightful little gem with private, standalone villas that are dotted across the 4,000-acre property. Spectacular vistas extend in every direction, and there are so many paths to explore, including those that lead to secluded beaches on the bay. After your arrival, a chef will meet with you to discuss a menu for your time in Akaroa. Expect locally sourced and seasonal ingredients that will add a creative flair to your cuisine.

dayInfo.title: Akaroa – Hot Air Ballooning Above the Canterbury Plains
dayInfo.description: By sunrise, you will be soaring above the Canterbury Plains. From the hot air balloon, you can admire a jigsaw puzzle of fields and pastures with each piece being its own specific hue. Sheep speckle some of this landscape, and in the distance, there will be the Pacific Ocean standing as an eternal image of your romantic vacation in New Zealand. After touching down on a remote field, your hot air balloon flight will be followed by a champagne brunch although it will not actually be Champagne from France, but New Zealand’s exquisite sparkling wine that is produced in the same manner. It is just as tasty and is more fitting given the environment. The rest of your day will be left free, and you can choose to do Akaroa’s most popular activity, which is swimming with Hector’s dolphins. These wild, ocean creatures dance and pirouette through the water, sometimes jumping many meters above the water’s surface. These animals are incredibly playful and enchanting. Seals are another highlight of these waters, and you can often spot whales as well, especially during the winter months. However, it is not an absolute guarantee that you will see the elusive whales. You can also choose to lay back and do nothing today. When custom-designed food is being delivered to your private villa, it will be easy to spend your afternoon drifting away.

dayInfo.title: Glenorchy – Highlights of Queenstown and Central Otago’s Wineries
dayInfo.description: Today, you will fly from Christchurch to Queenstown, and you will immediately understand why this part of New Zealand is so famous. Enormous mountains backdrop the small town, many of them being covered in snow for nine months of the year. Their peaks are reflected in Lake Wakatipu, which is a tranquil body of water that enhances the landscape with a delightful shade of blue. While Queenstown has a certain bustle, it is easy to be out in silence and away from the crowds on another piece of the lakeshore. Queenstown does have some cute shops and cafes that you may want to see, but the real highlight will be escaping the town to discover what is hidden on the surrounding Central Otago Plains. Vineyards are tucked into arid valleys, which private places from which you can continue the theme of escaping the world. Small lakes can be found away from the more popular Wakatipu. You can settle into a private tasting at two wineries that are not open to the public, or you can choose to walk hand in hand along a remote hiking trail. Your guide will meet you at Queenstown’s airport and offer you various options. Your day will be flexible, and there will be the opportunity to sample a range of highlights in Queenstown and Central Otago. At some point in the afternoon, you will arrive in Glenorchy, which is a tiny settlement on the opposite side of Lake Wakatipu. There is privacy and space here in addition to sublime views across the water.

dayInfo.title: Glenorchy – Scenic Helicopter Flight to Doubtful Sound
dayInfo.description: Evocative fjords cover New Zealand’s Southwest, and most of them are completely inaccessible by road, foot, or even boat. It is only from the air that you can truly appreciate this landscape, especially how the individual fjords are packed so tightly together. This morning, you will set off on a full day’s, VIP helicopter tour that includes three different landing points in Fiordland National Park. First, you will soar across the park, gaining an understanding of its scale. Then, you will touch down on a remote mountain escarpment where ice sculptures appear like poetic monuments to nature’s power. After flying across a lake, you will land at Doubtful Sound, where a boat tour will provide a stunning impression of a New Zealand fjord. Milford Sound is more famous, but the lack of other boats and visitors makes Doubtful Sound a nicer experience for couples. Cruising along the cliffs, you can admire waterfalls and seals, and then as the mist and clouds roll in, you can sense a primitive majesty to this cut-off land. On the flight back to Queenstown, you will make another stop. If the sky is clear, then you can stop on a mountain that provides stunning panoramas over the World Heritage fjords. If not, then you can stop inside one of the mountain valleys that cuts a stark path towards Queenstown. Here, you can appreciate just how big and humbling Southwestern New Zealand can be.

dayInfo.title: Queenstown – Departure
dayInfo.description: This morning will be left free, so you can enjoy a final lie in and some private moments along the lakeshore. You will be transferred privately to Queenstown Airport for your departing flight.

tourName: Private Paradise New Zealand North Island Tour for Couples
placesVisited: Kauri Cliffs, Taupo, Palliser Bay, Martinborough
generalInfo: Handcrafted to keep you away from crowds, this romantic, 12-day adventure celebrates destinations and experiences that are not usually available to the public. Romance thrives on New Zealand’s North Island, which is where you can escape the world on islands, volcanos, and backcountry wonder. Serenity floats on the breeze, and indulgence reigns at lodges that are hidden away. You can walk hand-in-hand upon landscapes that see very few visitors, helicopter to enchanting wilderness areas, be welcomed by the Maori, and bask in private spas.

dayInfo.title: Kauri Cliffs – Helicopter to the Northland
dayInfo.description: As you fly north, the landscape will blur into deep blue tones because this piece of New Zealand is dominated by the South Pacific Ocean. It is remote and wild out here, and, other than some famous kauri trees and Ninety Mile Beach, this area is not typically visited by international visitors. After landing at Auckland International Airport, you will be met by a guide and transferred to the helicopter for a short flight north. You will touch down near the Kauri Cliffs and check-in to your lodge that will be located on vast, private grounds. You may want to hideaway here for part of the afternoon, but you should definitely indulge in a stroll along the cliffs to three secluded Bay of Island beaches.

dayInfo.title: Kauri Cliffs – Bay of Islands Helicopter Tour
dayInfo.description: After lifting off from the Kauri Cliffs, you will fly across this iconic landscape en route to the Omarino Peninsula. From the sky, you can feast on the landscape before the pilot sets you down at some of North Island’s most important cultural and natural attractions. The Waitangi Treaty Grounds is where the Maori signed a peace agreement with the British, paving the way for a colony on the island. Russell is a romantic township that is dominated by 19th-Century architecture and charming cafes. After these destinations, you may be craving a little more solitude, so the pilot can lead you to Hole in the Rock and Urupukapuka island, where you can drift off to the sounds of the surf.

dayInfo.title: Kauri Cliffs – Bay of Islands Boat Cruise
dayInfo.description: After a day exploring from the air, you will spend today discovering the Bay of Islands from the water. You will board a private sailing boat and will ease across the Pacific with your captain. Cruising the Bay of Islands can also impress the significance of Maori history in the area, and you may even pass a traditional Maori canoe. There will be space to relax beneath a covered deck, and you can also lounge at the front of the boat beneath the sun with only a gentle breeze for company. Like yesterday, this will be a private excursion, and your exact itinerary is completely customizable.

dayInfo.title: Kauri Cliffs – Intimate Maori Experience
dayInfo.description: By now, you will have overcome any jet lag and travel fatigue, and you will also have enjoyed a couple of leisurely mornings at your lodge, sleeping in and ordering breakfast to the room. An early start will be important today because the Maori believe the optimal time for a connection with the spiritual world is the time when the rest of the world is asleep. With a Maori guide, you will travel to Cape Reinga, where two oceans collide. It is an incredibly spiritual place, especially when you are informed of some of the old stories. From the coast to kauri trees, your experience will continue in Waipoua Forest, where you will discover why kauris are known as the fathers and guardians of the forest.

dayInfo.title: Taupo – Backcountry Exploration and Crystal Clear Pools
dayInfo.description: From the Bay of Islands, you will fly to Taupo via Auckland on two scheduled flights. Volcano views can be enjoyed from the airplane window, but you should not worry if you miss them because, tomorrow, you will be able to see them plenty. You can meander through the gardens of your accommodation to discover that the trails run into the backcountry, giving the lodge a wilderness feel as well.
